description: Roslyn analyzers that spot Bugs, Vulnerabilities and Code Smells in your code. For an even better overall experience, you can use SonarLint for Visual Studio, which is a free extension (https://www.sonarlint.org/visualstudio/) that can be used standalone or with SonarQube (https://www.sonarqube.org/) and/or SonarCloud (https://sonarcloud.io/).

diagnostics.title: Methods and properties should be named in PascalCase
diagnostics.description: Shared naming conventions allow teams to collaborate efficiently. This rule checks whether or not method and property names are PascalCased. To reduce noise, two consecutive upper case characters are allowed unless they form the whole name. So, MyXMethod is compliant, but XM on its own is not.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Rename {0} '{1}' to match pascal case naming rules, {2}.

diagnostics.title: Method overrides should not change parameter defaults
diagnostics.description: Default arguments are determined by the static type of the object. If a default argument is different for a parameter in an overriding method, the value used in the call will be different when calls are made via the base or derived object, which may be contrary to developer expectations.
diagnostics.messageFormat: {0} the default parameter value {1}.

diagnostics.title: Types should be named in PascalCase
diagnostics.description: Shared naming conventions allow teams to collaborate efficiently. This rule checks whether or not type names are using PascalCase. To reduce noise, two consecutive upper case characters are allowed unless they form the whole type name. So, MyXClass is compliant, but XC on its own is not.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Rename {0} '{1}' to match pascal case naming rules, {2}.

diagnostics.title: Lines should not be too long
diagnostics.description: Having to scroll horizontally makes it harder to get a quick overview and understanding of any piece of code.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Split this {1} characters long line (which is greater than {0} authorized).

diagnostics.title: Files should not have too many lines of code
diagnostics.description: A source file that grows too much tends to aggregate too many responsibilities and inevitably becomes harder to understand and therefore to maintain. Above a specific threshold, it is strongly advised to refactor it into smaller pieces of code which focus on well defined tasks. Those smaller files will not only be easier to understand but also probably easier to test.
diagnostics.messageFormat: This file has {1} lines, which is greater than {0} authorized. Split it into smaller files.

diagnostics.title: Destructors should not throw exceptions
diagnostics.description: If Finalize or an override of Finalize throws an exception, and the runtime is not hosted by an application that overrides the default policy, the runtime terminates the process immediately without graceful cleanup (finally blocks and finalizers are not executed). This behavior ensures process integrity if the finalizer cannot free or destroy resources.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this 'throw' statement.

diagnostics.title: Tabulation characters should not be used
diagnostics.description: Developers should not need to configure the tab width of their text editors in order to be able to read source code.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Replace all tab characters in this file by sequences of white-spaces.

diagnostics.title: Standard outputs should not be used directly to log anything
diagnostics.description: When logging a message there are several important requirements which must be fulfilled:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this logging statement.

diagnostics.title: Collapsible "if" statements should be merged
diagnostics.description: Merging collapsible if statements increases the code's readability.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Merge this if statement with the enclosing one.

diagnostics.title: Expressions should not be too complex
diagnostics.description: The complexity of an expression is defined by the number of &&, || and condition ? ifTrue : ifFalse operators it contains.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Reduce the number of conditional operators ({1}) used in the expression (maximum allowed {0}).

diagnostics.title: Methods should not have too many parameters
diagnostics.description: A long parameter list can indicate that a new structure should be created to wrap the numerous parameters or that the function is doing too many things.
diagnostics.messageFormat: {0} has {1} parameters, which is greater than the {2} authorized.

diagnostics.title: URIs should not be hardcoded
diagnostics.description: Hardcoding a URI makes it difficult to test a program: path literals are not always portable across operating systems, a given absolute path may not exist on a specific test environment, a specified Internet URL may not be available when executing the tests, production environment filesystems usually differ from the development environment, ...etc. For all those reasons, a URI should never be hardcoded. Instead, it should be replaced by customizable parameter.

diagnostics.title: Nested blocks of code should not be left empty
diagnostics.description: Most of the time a block of code is empty when a piece of code is really missing. So such empty block must be either filled or removed.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Either remove or fill this block of code.

diagnostics.title: Magic numbers should not be used
diagnostics.description: A magic number is a number that comes out of nowhere, and is directly used in a statement. Magic numbers are often used, for instance to limit the number of iterations of a loop, to test the value of a property, etc.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Assign this magic number '{0}' to a well-named (variable|constant), and use the (variable|constant) instead.

diagnostics.title: Inheritance tree of classes should not be too deep
diagnostics.description: Inheritance is certainly one of the most valuable concepts in object-oriented programming. It's a way to compartmentalize and reuse code by creating collections of attributes and behaviors called classes which can be based on previously created classes. But abusing this concept by creating a deep inheritance tree can lead to very complex and unmaintainable source code. Most of the time a too deep inheritance tree is due to bad object oriented design which has led to systematically use 'inheritance' when for instance 'composition' would suit better.
diagnostics.messageFormat: This class has {0} parents which is greater than {1} authorized.

diagnostics.title: Fields should not have public accessibility
diagnostics.description: Public fields in public classes do not respect the encapsulation principle and has three main disadvantages:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make this field 'private' and encapsulate it in a 'public' property.

diagnostics.title: A close curly brace should be located at the beginning of a line
diagnostics.description: Shared coding conventions make it possible for a team to efficiently collaborate. This rule makes it mandatory to place a close curly brace at the beginning of a line.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Move this closing curly brace to the next line.

diagnostics.title: Redundant pairs of parentheses should be removed
diagnostics.description: The use of parentheses, even those not required to enforce a desired order of operations, can clarify the intent behind a piece of code. But redundant pairs of parentheses could be misleading, and should be removed.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove these redundant parentheses.

diagnostics.title: Empty statements should be removed
diagnostics.description: Empty statements, i.e. ;, are usually introduced by mistake, for example because:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this empty statement.

diagnostics.title: Local variables should not shadow class fields
diagnostics.description: Overriding or shadowing a variable declared in an outer scope can strongly impact the readability, and therefore the maintainability, of a piece of code. Further, it could lead maintainers to introduce bugs because they think they're using one variable but are really using another.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Rename '{0}' which hides the {1} with the same name.

diagnostics.title: Utility classes should not have public constructors
diagnostics.description: Utility classes, which are collections of static members, are not meant to be instantiated.

diagnostics.title: General exceptions should never be thrown
diagnostics.description: Throwing such general exceptions as Exception, SystemException, ApplicationException, IndexOutOfRangeException, NullReferenceException, OutOfMemoryException and ExecutionEngineException prevents calling methods from handling true, system-generated exceptions differently than application-generated errors.
diagnostics.messageFormat: '{0}' should not be thrown by user code.

diagnostics.title: Assignments should not be made from within sub-expressions
diagnostics.description: Assignments within sub-expressions are hard to spot and therefore make the code less readable. Ideally, sub-expressions should not have side-effects.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Extract the assignment of '{0}' from this expression.

diagnostics.title: "Obsolete" attributes should include explanations
diagnostics.description: The Obsolete attribute can be applied with or without arguments, but marking something Obsolete without including advice as to why it's obsolete or on what to use instead will lead maintainers to waste time trying to figure those things out - every single time the warning is encountered.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Add an explanation.

diagnostics.title: Boolean literals should not be redundant
diagnostics.description: Redundant Boolean literals should be removed from expressions to improve readability.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove the unnecessary Boolean literal(s).

diagnostics.title: Unused "using" should be removed
diagnostics.description: Although unnecessary using won't change anything to the produced application, removing them:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this unnecessary 'using'.

diagnostics.title: Files should contain an empty newline at the end
diagnostics.description: Some tools work better when files end with an empty line.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Add a new line at the end of the file '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: Track uses of "FIXME" tags
diagnostics.description: FIXME tags are commonly used to mark places where a bug is suspected, but which the developer wants to deal with later.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Take the required action to fix the issue indicated by this 'FIXME' comment.

diagnostics.title: Track uses of "TODO" tags
diagnostics.description: TODO tags are commonly used to mark places where some more code is required, but which the developer wants to implement later.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Complete the task associated to this 'TODO' comment.

diagnostics.title: Unused private types or members should be removed
diagnostics.description: private or internal types or private members that are never executed or referenced are dead code: unnecessary, inoperative code that should be removed. Cleaning out dead code decreases the size of the maintained codebase, making it easier to understand the program and preventing bugs from being introduced.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove the unused {0} {1} '{2}'.

diagnostics.title: Useless "if(true) {...}" and "if(false){...}" blocks should be removed
diagnostics.description: if statements with conditions that are always false have the effect of making blocks of code non-functional. if statements with conditions that are always true are completely redundant, and make the code less readable.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this useless {0}.

diagnostics.title: Exit methods should not be called
diagnostics.description: Calling Environment.Exit(exitCode) or Application.Exit() terminates the process and returns an exit code to the operating system..
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this call to '{0}' or ensure it is really required.

diagnostics.title: "switch case" clauses should not have too many lines of code
diagnostics.description: The switch statement should be used only to clearly define some new branches in the control flow. As soon as a case clause contains too many statements this highly decreases the readability of the overall control flow statement. In such case, the content of the case clause should be extracted into a dedicated method.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Reduce this {0} number of statements from {1} to at most {2}, for example by extracting code into a {3}.

diagnostics.title: "Any()" should be used to test for emptiness
diagnostics.description: Using .Count() to test for emptiness works, but using .Any() makes the intent clearer, and the code more readable. However, there are some cases where special attention should be paid:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use '.Any()' to test whether this 'IEnumerable<{0}>' is empty or not.

diagnostics.title: Exceptions should not be thrown in finally blocks
diagnostics.description: Throwing an exception from within a finally block will mask any exception which was previously thrown in the try or catch block, and the masked's exception message and stack trace will be lost.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor this code to not throw exceptions in finally blocks.

diagnostics.title: Empty arrays and collections should be returned instead of null
diagnostics.description: Returning null instead of an actual array or collection forces callers of the method to explicitly test for nullity, making them more complex and less readable.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Return an empty collection instead of null.

diagnostics.title: Unused method parameters should be removed
diagnostics.description: Unused parameters are misleading. Whatever the values passed to such parameters, the behavior will be the same.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this {0}.

diagnostics.title: Overriding members should do more than simply call the same member in the base class
diagnostics.description: Overriding a method just to call the same method from the base class without performing any other actions is useless and misleading. The only time this is justified is in sealed overriding methods, where the effect is to lock in the parent class behavior. This rule ignores overrides of Equals and GetHashCode.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this {1} '{0}' to simply inherit its behavior.

diagnostics.title: Methods should not be empty
diagnostics.description: There are several reasons for a method not to have a method body:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Add a nested comment explaining why this method is empty, throw a 'NotSupportedException' or complete the implementation.

diagnostics.title: String literals should not be duplicated
diagnostics.description: Duplicated string literals make the process of refactoring error-prone, since you must be sure to update all occurrences.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Define a constant instead of using this literal '{0}' {1} times.

diagnostics.title: Nested code blocks should not be used
diagnostics.description: Nested code blocks can be used to create a new scope and restrict the visibility of the variables defined inside it. Using this feature in a method typically indicates that the method has too many responsibilities, and should be refactored into smaller methods.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Extract this nested code block into a separate method.

diagnostics.title: Classes should not be coupled to too many other classes (Single Responsibility Principle)
diagnostics.description: According to the Single Responsibility Principle, introduced by Robert C. Martin in his book "Principles of Object Oriented Design", a class should have only one responsibility:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Split this {0} into smaller and more specialized ones to reduce its dependencies on other classes from {1} to the maximum authorized {2} or less.

diagnostics.title: "Equals(Object)" and "GetHashCode()" should be overridden in pairs
diagnostics.description: There is a contract between Equals(object) and GetHashCode(): If two objects are equal according to the Equals(object) method, then calling GetHashCode() on each of them must yield the same result. If this is not the case, many collections won't handle class instances correctly.
diagnostics.messageFormat: This {0} overrides '{1}' and should therefore also override '{2}'.

diagnostics.title: Control structures should use curly braces
diagnostics.description: While not technically incorrect, the omission of curly braces can be misleading, and may lead to the introduction of errors during maintenance.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Add curly braces around the nested statement(s) in this '{0}' block.

diagnostics.title: "Equals" and the comparison operators should be overridden when implementing "IComparable"
diagnostics.description: When you implement IComparable or IComparable<T> on a class you should also override Equals(object) and overload the comparison operators (==, !=, <, <=, >, >=). That's because the CLR cannot automatically call your CompareTo implementation from Equals(object) or from the base comparison operator implementations. Additionally, it is best practice to override GetHashCode along with Equals.
diagnostics.messageFormat: When implementing {0}, you should also override {1}.

diagnostics.title: "GC.Collect" should not be called
diagnostics.description: Calling GC.Collect is rarely necessary, and can significantly affect application performance. That's because it triggers a blocking operation that examines every object in memory for cleanup. Further, you don't have control over when this blocking cleanup will actually run.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor the code to remove this use of '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: Statements should be on separate lines
diagnostics.description: For better readability, do not put more than one statement on a single line.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Reformat the code to have only one statement per line.

diagnostics.title: Method parameters, caught exceptions and foreach variables' initial values should not be ignored
diagnostics.description: While it is technically correct to assign to parameters from within method bodies, doing so before the parameter value is read is likely a bug. Instead, initial values of parameters, caught exceptions, and foreach parameters should be, if not treated as final, then at least read before reassignment.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Introduce a new variable instead of reusing the parameter '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: break statements should not be used except for switch cases
diagnostics.description: break; is an unstructured control flow statement which makes code harder to read.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor the code in order to remove this break statement.

diagnostics.title: Floating point numbers should not be tested for equality
diagnostics.description: Floating point math is imprecise because of the challenges of storing such values in a binary representation. Even worse, floating point math is not associative; push a float or a double through a series of simple mathematical operations and the answer will be different based on the order of those operation because of the rounding that takes place at each step.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Do not check floating point {0} with exact values, use a range instead.

diagnostics.title: Sections of code should not be commented out
diagnostics.description: Programmers should not comment out code as it bloats programs and reduces readability.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this commented out code.

diagnostics.title: "if ... else if" constructs should end with "else" clauses
diagnostics.description: This rule applies whenever an if statement is followed by one or more else if statements; the final else if should be followed by an else statement.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Add the missing 'else' clause.

diagnostics.title: A "while" loop should be used instead of a "for" loop
diagnostics.description: When only the condition expression is defined in a for loop, and the initialization and increment expressions are missing, a while loop should be used instead to increase readability.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Replace this 'for' loop with a 'while' loop.

diagnostics.title: "for" loop stop conditions should be invariant
diagnostics.description: A for loop stop condition should test the loop counter against an invariant value (i.e. one that is true at both the beginning and ending of every loop iteration). Ideally, this means that the stop condition is set to a local variable just before the loop begins.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Do not update the loop counter '{0}' within the loop body.

diagnostics.title: "switch" statements should have at least 3 "case" clauses
diagnostics.description: switch statements and expressions are useful when there are many different cases depending on the value of the same expression.

diagnostics.title: Track uses of in-source issue suppressions
diagnostics.description: This rule allows you to track the usage of the SuppressMessage attributes and #pragma warning disable mechanism.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Do not suppress issues.

diagnostics.title: "switch/Select" statements should contain a "default/Case Else" clauses
diagnostics.description: The requirement for a final default clause is defensive programming. The clause should either take appropriate action, or contain a suitable comment as to why no action is taken. Even when the switch covers all current values of an enum, a default case should still be used because there is no guarantee that the enum won't be extended.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Add a '{0}' clause to this '{1}' statement.

diagnostics.title: Using hardcoded IP addresses is security-sensitive
diagnostics.description: Hardcoding IP addresses is security-sensitive. It has led in the past to the following vulnerabilities:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make sure using this hardcoded IP address '{0}' is safe here.

diagnostics.title: Control flow statements "if", "switch", "for", "foreach", "while", "do"  and "try" should not be nested too deeply
diagnostics.description: Nested if, switch, for, foreach, while, do, and try statements are key ingredients for making what's known as "Spaghetti code".
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor this code to not nest more than {0} control flow statements.

diagnostics.title: Functions should not have too many lines of code
diagnostics.description: A function that grows too large tends to aggregate too many responsibilities.
diagnostics.messageFormat: This {0} has {1} lines, which is greater than the {2} lines authorized. Split it into smaller {3}.

diagnostics.title: Culture should be specified for "string" operations
diagnostics.description: string.ToLower(), ToUpper, IndexOf, LastIndexOf, and Compare are all culture-dependent, as are some (floating point number and DateTime-related) calls to ToString. Fortunately, all have variants which accept an argument specifying the culture or formatter to use. Leave that argument off and the call will use the system default culture, possibly creating problems with international characters.

diagnostics.title: Private fields only used as local variables in methods should become local variables
diagnostics.description: When the value of a private field is always assigned to in a class' methods before being read, then it is not being used to store class information. Therefore, it should become a local variable in the relevant methods to prevent any misunderstanding.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove the field '{0}' and declare it as a local variable in the relevant methods.

diagnostics.title: Track lack of copyright and license headers
diagnostics.description: Each source file should start with a header stating file ownership and the license which must be used to distribute the application.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Add or update the header of this file.

diagnostics.title: "switch" statements should not have too many "case" clauses
diagnostics.description: When switch statements have large sets of case clauses, it is usually an attempt to map two sets of data. A Dictionary should be used instead to make the code more readable and maintainable.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Consider reworking this 'switch' to reduce the number of 'case's from {1} to at most {0}.

diagnostics.title: Unused local variables should be removed
diagnostics.description: If a local variable is declared but not used, it is dead code and should be removed. Doing so will improve maintainability because developers will not wonder what the variable is used for.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove the unused local variable '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: Methods and properties should not be too complex
diagnostics.description: The cyclomatic complexity of methods and properties should not exceed a defined threshold. Complex code can perform poorly and will in any case be difficult to understand and therefore to maintain.
diagnostics.messageFormat: The Cyclomatic Complexity of this {2} is {1} which is greater than {0} authorized.

diagnostics.title: Tests should not be ignored
diagnostics.description: When a test fails due, for example, to infrastructure issues, you might want to ignore it temporarily. But without some kind of notation about why the test is being ignored, it may never be reactivated. Such tests are difficult to address without comprehensive knowledge of the project, and end up polluting their projects.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Either remove this 'Ignore' attribute or add an explanation about why this test is ignored.

diagnostics.title: Strings should not be concatenated using '+' in a loop
diagnostics.description: StringBuilder is more efficient than string concatenation, especially when the operator is repeated over and over as in loops.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use a StringBuilder instead.

diagnostics.title: Variables should not be self-assigned
diagnostics.description: There is no reason to re-assign a variable to itself. Either this statement is redundant and should be removed, or the re-assignment is a mistake and some other value or variable was intended for the assignment instead.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove or correct this useless self-assignment.

diagnostics.title: Multiple variables should not be declared on the same line
diagnostics.description: Declaring multiple variable on one line is difficult to read.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Declare '{0}' in a separate statement.

diagnostics.title: An abstract class should have both abstract and concrete methods
diagnostics.description: The purpose of an abstract class is to provide some heritable behaviors while also defining methods which must be implemented by sub-classes.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Convert this 'abstract' class to {0}.

diagnostics.title: NullReferenceException should not be caught
diagnostics.description: NullReferenceException should be avoided, not caught. Any situation in which NullReferenceException is explicitly caught can easily be converted to a null test, and any behavior being carried out in the catch block can easily be moved to the "is null" branch of the conditional.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Do not catch NullReferenceException; test for null instead.

diagnostics.title: Short-circuit logic should be used to prevent null pointer dereferences in conditionals
diagnostics.description: When either the equality operator in a null test or the logical operator that follows it is reversed, the code has the appearance of safely null-testing the object before dereferencing it. Unfortunately the effect is just the opposite - the object is null-tested and then dereferenced only if it is null, leading to a guaranteed null pointer dereference.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Either reverse the equality operator in the '{0}' null test, or reverse the logical operator that follows it.

diagnostics.title: "==" should not be used when "Equals" is overridden
diagnostics.description: Using the equality == and inequality != operators to compare two objects generally works. The operators can be overloaded, and therefore the comparison can resolve to the appropriate method. However, when the operators are used on interface instances, then == resolves to reference equality, which may result in unexpected behavior if implementing classes override Equals. Similarly, when a class overrides Equals, but instances are compared with non-overloaded ==, there is a high chance that value comparison was meant instead of the reference one.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Consider using 'Equals' if value comparison was intended.

diagnostics.title: Constructors should only call non-overridable methods
diagnostics.description: Calling an overridable method from a constructor could result in failures or strange behaviors when instantiating a subclass which overrides the method.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this call from a constructor to the overridable '{0}' method.

diagnostics.title: Loops with at most one iteration should be refactored
diagnostics.description: A loop with at most one iteration is equivalent to the use of an if statement to conditionally execute one piece of code. If the initial intention of the author was really to conditionally execute one piece of code, an if statement should be used instead. If that was not the initial intention of the author, the body of the loop should be fixed to use the nested return, break or throw statements in a more appropriate way.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor the containing loop to do more than one iteration.

diagnostics.title: Identical expressions should not be used on both sides of a binary operator
diagnostics.description: Using the same value on either side of a binary operator is almost always a mistake. In the case of logical operators, it is either a copy/paste error and therefore a bug, or it is simply wasted code, and should be simplified. In the case of bitwise operators and most binary mathematical operators, having the same value on both sides of an operator yields predictable results, and should be simplified.

diagnostics.title: "switch" statements should not be nested
diagnostics.description: Nested switch structures are difficult to understand because you can easily confuse the cases of an inner switch as belonging to an outer statement. Therefore nested switch statements should be avoided.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor the code to eliminate this nested 'switch'.

diagnostics.title: Objects should not be created to be dropped immediately without being used
diagnostics.description: There is no good reason to create a new object to not do anything with it. Most of the time, this is due to a missing piece of code and so could lead to an unexpected behavior in production.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Either remove this useless object instantiation of class '{0}' or use it.

diagnostics.title: Unused assignments should be removed
diagnostics.description: A dead store happens when a local variable is assigned a value that is not read by any subsequent instruction. Calculating or retrieving a value only to then overwrite it or throw it away, could indicate a serious error in the code. Even if it's not an error, it is at best a waste of resources. Therefore all calculated values should be used.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this useless assignment to local variable '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: "ToString()" calls should not be redundant
diagnostics.description: Invoking a method designed to return a string representation of an object which is already a string is a waste of keystrokes. Similarly, explicitly invoking ToString() when the compiler would do it implicitly is also needless code-bloat.
diagnostics.messageFormat: There's no need to call 'ToString()'{0}.

diagnostics.title: Related "if/else if" statements should not have the same condition
diagnostics.description: A chain of if/else if statements is evaluated from top to bottom. At most, only one branch will be executed: the first one with a condition that evaluates to true.
diagnostics.messageFormat: This branch duplicates the one on line {0}.

diagnostics.title: Two branches in a conditional structure should not have exactly the same implementation
diagnostics.description: Having two cases in the same switch statement or branches in the same if structure with the same implementation is at best duplicate code, and at worst a coding error. If the same logic is truly needed for both instances, then in an if structure they should be combined, or for a switch, one should fall through to the other.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Either merge this {1} with the identical one on line {0} or change one of the implementations.

diagnostics.title: Redundant casts should not be used
diagnostics.description: Unnecessary casting expressions make the code harder to read and understand.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this unnecessary cast to '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: Inheritance list should not be redundant
diagnostics.description: An inheritance list entry is redundant if:

diagnostics.title: Boolean checks should not be inverted
diagnostics.description: It is needlessly complex to invert the result of a boolean comparison. The opposite comparison should be made instead.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use the opposite operator ('{0}') instead.

diagnostics.title: Inappropriate casts should not be made
diagnostics.description: Inappropriate casts are issues that will lead to unexpected behavior or runtime errors, such as InvalidCastExceptions. The compiler will catch bad casts from one class to another, but not bad casts to interfaces. Nor will it catch nullable values that are known to be null but that are cast to their underlying value types anyway.

diagnostics.title: Inappropriate casts should not be made
diagnostics.description: Inappropriate casts are issues that will lead to unexpected behavior or runtime errors, such as InvalidCastExceptions. The compiler will catch bad casts from one class to another, but not bad casts to interfaces. Nor will it catch nullable values that are known to be null but that are cast to their underlying value types anyway.

diagnostics.title: "for" loop increment clauses should modify the loops' counters
diagnostics.description: It can be extremely confusing when a for loop's counter is incremented outside of its increment clause. In such cases, the increment should be moved to the loop's increment clause if at all possible.

diagnostics.title: Hashes should include an unpredictable salt
diagnostics.description: In cryptography, "salt" is extra piece of data which is included in a hashing algorithm. It makes dictionary attacks more difficult. Using a cryptographic hash function without an unpredictable salt increases the likelihood that an attacker will be able to successfully guess a hashed value such as a password with a dictionary attack.

diagnostics.title: Hard-coded credentials are security-sensitive
diagnostics.description: Because it is easy to extract strings from an application source code or binary, credentials should not be hard-coded. This is particularly true for applications that are distributed or that are open-source.

diagnostics.title: SHA-1 and Message-Digest hash algorithms should not be used in secure contexts
diagnostics.description: The MD5 algorithm and its successor, SHA-1, are no longer considered secure, because it is too easy to create hash collisions with them. That is, it takes too little computational effort to come up with a different input that produces the same MD5 or SHA-1 hash, and using the new, same-hash value gives an attacker the same access as if he had the originally-hashed value. This applies as well to the other Message-Digest algorithms: MD2, MD4, MD6.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use a stronger hashing/asymmetric algorithm.

diagnostics.title: Formatting SQL queries is security-sensitive
diagnostics.description: Formatting strings used as SQL queries is security-sensitive. It has led in the past to the following vulnerabilities:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make sure that executing SQL queries is safe here.

diagnostics.title: Creating cookies without the "secure" flag is security-sensitive
diagnostics.description: When a cookie is protected with the secure attribute set to true it will not be send by the browser over an unencrypted HTTP request and thus cannot be observed by an unauthorized person during a man-in-the-middle attack.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make sure creating this cookie without setting the 'Secure' property is safe here.

diagnostics.title: Collections should not be passed as arguments to their own methods
diagnostics.description: Passing a collection as an argument to the collection's own method is either an error - some other argument was intended - or simply nonsensical code.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Change one instance of '{0}' to a different value; {1}

diagnostics.title: Values should not be uselessly incremented
diagnostics.description: A value that is incremented or decremented and then not stored is at best wasted code and at worst a bug.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this {0} or correct the code not to waste it.

diagnostics.title: Underscores should be used to make large numbers readable
diagnostics.description: Beginning with C# 7, it is possible to add underscores ('_') to numeric literals to enhance readability. The addition of underscores in this manner has no semantic meaning, but makes it easier for maintainers to understand the code.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Add underscores to this numeric value for readability.

diagnostics.title: "sealed" classes should not have "protected" members
diagnostics.description: The difference between private and protected visibility is that child classes can see and use protected members, but they cannot see private ones. Since a sealed class cannot have children, marking its members protected is confusingly pointless.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this 'protected' modifier.

diagnostics.title: Short-circuit logic should be used in boolean contexts
diagnostics.description: The use of non-short-circuit logic in a boolean context is likely a mistake - one that could cause serious program errors as conditions are evaluated under the wrong circumstances.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Correct this '{0}' to '{1}'.

diagnostics.title: Integral numbers should not be shifted by zero or more than their number of bits-1
diagnostics.description: Shifting an integral number by 0 is equivalent to doing nothing but makes the code confusing for maintainers.

diagnostics.title: Results of integer division should not be assigned to floating point variables
diagnostics.description: When division is performed on ints, the result will always be an int. You can assign that result to a double, float or decimal with automatic type conversion, but having started as an int, the result will likely not be what you expect. If the result of int division is assigned to a floating-point variable, precision will have been lost before the assignment. Instead, at least one operand should be cast or promoted to the final type before the operation takes place.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Cast one of the operands of this division to '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: TestCases should contain tests
diagnostics.description: There's no point in having a test class without any test methods.This could lead a maintainer to assume a class is covered by tests even though it is not.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Add some tests to this class.

diagnostics.title: Recursion should not be infinite
diagnostics.description: Recursion happens when control enters a loop that has no exit. This can happen a method invokes itself, when a pair of methods invoke each other, or when goto statements are used to move between two segments of code. It can be a useful tool, but unless the method includes a provision to break out of the recursion and return, the recursion will continue until the stack overflows and the program crashes.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Add a way to break out of this {0}.

diagnostics.title: Modulus results should not be checked for direct equality
diagnostics.description: When the modulus of a negative number is calculated, the result will either be negative or zero. Thus, comparing the modulus of a variable for equality with a positive number (or a negative one) could result in unexpected results.
diagnostics.messageFormat: The result of this modulus operation may not be {0}.

diagnostics.title: Return values from functions without side effects should not be ignored
diagnostics.description: When the call to a function doesn't have any side effects, what is the point of making the call if the results are ignored? In such case, either the function call is useless and should be dropped or the source code doesn't behave as expected.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use the return value of method '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: Runtime type checking should be simplified
diagnostics.description: To check the type of an object there are several options:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use {0} instead.

diagnostics.title: "Exception" should not be caught when not required by called methods
diagnostics.description: Catching System.Exception seems like an efficient way to handle multiple possible exceptions. Unfortunately, it traps all exception types, including the ones that were not intended to be caught. To prevent any misunderstandings, the exception filters should be used. Alternatively each exception type should be in a separate catch block.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Catch a list of specific exception subtype or use exception filters instead.

diagnostics.title: Non-constant static fields should not be visible
diagnostics.description: A static field that is neither constant nor read-only is not thread-safe. Correctly accessing these fields from different threads needs synchronization with locks. Improper synchronization may lead to unexpected results, thus publicly visible static fields are best suited for storing non-changing data shared by many consumers. To enforce this intent, these fields should be marked readonly or converted to constants.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Change the visibility of '{0}' or make it 'const' or 'readonly'.

diagnostics.title: "ToString()" method should not return null
diagnostics.description: Calling ToString() on an object should always return a string. Returning null instead contravenes the method's implicit contract.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Return empty string instead.

diagnostics.title: Console logging should not be used
diagnostics.description: Debug statements are always useful during development. But include them in production code - particularly in code that runs client-side - and you run the risk of inadvertently exposing sensitive information.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this logging statement.

diagnostics.title: Parameters should be passed in the correct order
diagnostics.description: When the names of parameters in a method call match the names of the method arguments, it contributes to clearer, more readable code. However, when the names match, but are passed in a different order than the method arguments, it indicates a mistake in the parameter order which will likely lead to unexpected results.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Parameters to '{0}' have the same names but not the same order as the method arguments.

diagnostics.title: Using pseudorandom number generators (PRNGs) is security-sensitive
diagnostics.description: Using pseudorandom number generators (PRNGs) is security-sensitive. For example, it has led in the past to the following vulnerabilities:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make sure that using this pseudorandom number generator is safe here.

diagnostics.title: A "for" loop update clause should move the counter in the right direction
diagnostics.description: A for loop with a counter that moves in the wrong direction is not an infinite loop. Because of wraparound, the loop will eventually reach its stop condition, but in doing so, it will run many, many more times than anticipated, potentially causing unexpected behavior.
diagnostics.messageFormat: '{0}' is {1}remented and will never reach 'stop condition'.

diagnostics.title: For-loop conditions should be true at least once
diagnostics.description: If a for loop's condition is false before the first loop iteration, the loop will never be executed. Such loops are almost always bugs, particularly when the initial value and stop conditions are hard-coded.
diagnostics.messageFormat: This loop will never execute.

diagnostics.title: Writing cookies is security-sensitive
diagnostics.description: Using cookies is security-sensitive. It has led in the past to the following vulnerabilities:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make sure that this cookie is written safely.

diagnostics.title: Using non-standard cryptographic algorithms is security-sensitive
diagnostics.description: The use of a non-standard algorithm is dangerous because a determined attacker may be able to break the algorithm and compromise whatever data has been protected. Standard algorithms like AES, RSA, SHA, ... should be used instead.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make sure using a non-standard cryptographic algorithm is safe here.

diagnostics.title: Null pointers should not be dereferenced
diagnostics.description: A reference to null should never be dereferenced/accessed. Doing so will cause a NullReferenceException to be thrown. At best, such an exception will cause abrupt program termination. At worst, it could expose debugging information that would be useful to an attacker, or it could allow an attacker to bypass security measures.
diagnostics.messageFormat: '{0}' is null on at least one execution path.

diagnostics.title: Composite format strings should not lead to unexpected behavior at runtime
diagnostics.description: Because composite format strings are interpreted at runtime, rather than validated by the compiler, they can contain errors that lead to unexpected behaviors or runtime errors. This rule statically validates the good behavior of composite formats when calling the methods of String.Format, StringBuilder.AppendFormat, Console.Write, Console.WriteLine, TextWriter.Write, TextWriter.WriteLine, Debug.WriteLine(String,Object[]), Trace.TraceError(String,Object[]), Trace.TraceInformation(String,Object[]), Trace.TraceWarning(String,Object[]) and TraceSource.TraceInformation(String,Object[]).

diagnostics.title: Neither DES (Data Encryption Standard) nor DESede (3DES) should be used
diagnostics.description: According to the US National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), the Data Encryption Standard (DES) is no longer considered secure:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use the recommended AES (Advanced Encryption Standard) instead.

diagnostics.title: Field-like events should not be virtual
diagnostics.description: Field-like events are events that do not have explicit add and remove methods. The compiler generates a private delegate field to back the event, as well as generating the implicit add and remove methods.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this 'virtual' modifier of {0}.

diagnostics.title: Overflow checking should not be disabled for "Enumerable.Sum"
diagnostics.description: Enumerable.Sum() always executes addition in a checked context, so an OverflowException will be thrown if the value exceeds MaxValue even if an unchecked context was specified. Using an unchecked context anyway represents a misunderstanding of how Sum works.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor this code to handle 'OverflowException'.

diagnostics.title: Trivial properties should be auto-implemented
diagnostics.description: Trivial properties, which include no logic but setting and getting a backing field should be converted to auto-implemented properties, yielding cleaner and more readable code.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make this an auto-implemented property and remove its backing field.

diagnostics.title: "nameof" should be used
diagnostics.description: Because parameter names could be changed during refactoring, they should not be spelled out literally in strings. Instead, use nameof(), and the string that's output will always be correct.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Replace the string '{0}' with 'nameof({0})'.

diagnostics.title: "async" and "await" should not be used as identifiers
diagnostics.description: Since C# 5.0, async and await are contextual keywords. Contextual keywords do have a particular meaning in some contexts, but can still be used as variable names. Keywords, on the other hand, are always reserved, and therefore are not valid variable names. To avoid any confusion though, it is best to not use async and await as identifiers.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Rename '{0}' to not use a contextual keyword as an identifier.

diagnostics.title: Methods and properties that don't access instance data should be static
diagnostics.description: Methods and properties that don't access instance data can be static to prevent any misunderstanding about the contract of the method.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make '{0}' a static {1}.

diagnostics.title: Unused type parameters should be removed
diagnostics.description: Type parameters that aren't used are dead code, which can only distract and possibly confuse developers during maintenance. Therefore, unused type parameters should be removed.
diagnostics.messageFormat: '{0}' is not used in the {1}.

diagnostics.title: "try" statements with identical "catch" and/or "finally" blocks should be merged
diagnostics.description: When multiple, adjacent try statements have duplicate catch and/or finally blocks, they should be merged to consolidate the catch/finally logic for cleaner, more readable code. Note that this applies even when there is intervening code outside any try block.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Combine this 'try' with the one starting on line {0}.

diagnostics.title: "GetHashCode" should not reference mutable fields
diagnostics.description: GetHashCode is used to file an object in a Dictionary or Hashtable. If GetHashCode uses non-readonly fields and those fields change after the object is stored, the object immediately becomes mis-filed in the Hashtable. Any subsequent test to see if the object is in the Hashtable will return a false negative.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor 'GetHashCode' to not reference mutable fields.

diagnostics.title: Array covariance should not be used
diagnostics.description: Array covariance is the principle that if an implicit or explicit reference conversion exits from type A to B, then the same conversion exists from the array type A[] to B[].
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor the code to not rely on potentially unsafe array conversions.

diagnostics.title: Redundant modifiers should not be used
diagnostics.description: Unnecessary keywords simply clutter the code and should be removed. Specifically:
diagnostics.messageFormat: '{0}' is {1} in this context.

diagnostics.title: Public constant members should not be used
diagnostics.description: Constant members are copied at compile time to the call sites, instead of being fetched at runtime.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Change this constant to a {0} property.

diagnostics.title: Enumeration types should comply with a naming convention
diagnostics.description: Shared naming conventions allow teams to collaborate efficiently. This rule checks that all enum names match a provided regular expression.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Rename this enumeration to match the regular expression: '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: Enumeration type names should not have "Flags" or "Enum" suffixes
diagnostics.description: The information that an enumeration type is actually an enumeration or a set of flags should not be duplicated in its name.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Rename this enumeration to remove the '{0}' suffix.

diagnostics.title: Flags enumerations should explicitly initialize all their members
diagnostics.description: Flags enumerations should not rely on the language to initialize the values of their members. Implicit initialization will set the first member to 0, and increment the value by one for each subsequent member. This implicit behavior does not allow members to be combined using the bitwise or operator in a useful way.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Initialize all the members of this 'Flags' enumeration.

diagnostics.title: Flags enumerations zero-value members should be named "None"
diagnostics.description: Consistent use of "None" in flags enumerations indicates that all flag values are cleared. The value 0 should not be used to indicate any other state, since there is no way to check that the bit 0 is set.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Rename '{0}' to 'None'.

diagnostics.title: Fields should be private
diagnostics.description: Fields should not be part of an API, and therefore should always be private. Indeed, they cannot be added to an interface for instance, and validation cannot be added later on without breaking backward compatibility. Instead, developers should encapsulate their fields into properties. Explicit property getters and setters can be introduced for validation purposes or to smooth the transition to a newer system.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make '{0}' private.

diagnostics.title: Optional parameters should not be used
diagnostics.description: The overloading mechanism should be used in place of optional parameters for several reasons:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use the overloading mechanism instead of the optional parameters.

diagnostics.title: Properties should not make collection or array copies
diagnostics.description: Most developers expect property access to be as efficient as field access. However, if a property returns a copy of an array or collection, it will be much slower than simple field access, contrary to the caller's likely expectations. Therefore, such properties should be refactored into methods so that callers are not surprised by the unexpectedly poor performance.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor '{0}' into a method, properties should not copy collections.

diagnostics.title: Public methods should not have multidimensional array parameters
diagnostics.description: Exposing methods with multidimensional array parameters requires developers to have advanced knowledge about the language in order to be able to use them. Moreover, what exactly to pass to such parameters is not intuitive. Therefore, such methods should not be exposed, but can be used internally.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make this method private or simplify its parameters to not use multidimensional arrays.

diagnostics.title: Exceptions should not be thrown from property getters
diagnostics.description: Property getters should be simple operations that are always safe to call. If exceptions need to be thrown, it is best to convert the property to a method.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove the exception throwing from this property getter, or refactor the property into a method.

diagnostics.title: Write-only properties should not be used
diagnostics.description: Properties with only setters are confusing and counterintuitive. Instead, a property getter should be added if possible, or the property should be replaced with a setter method.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Provide a getter for '{0}' or replace the property with a 'Set{0}' method.

diagnostics.title: Mutable fields should not be "public static"
diagnostics.description: public static mutable fields of classes which are accessed directly should be protected to the degree possible. This can be done by reducing the accessibility of the field or by changing the return type to an immutable type.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use an immutable collection or reduce the accessibility of the field(s) {0}.

diagnostics.title: Child class fields should not shadow parent class fields
diagnostics.description: Having a variable with the same name in two unrelated classes is fine, but do the same thing within a class hierarchy and you'll get confusion at best, chaos at worst.
diagnostics.messageFormat: '{0}' is the name of a field in '{1}'.

diagnostics.title: Types and methods should not have too many generic parameters
diagnostics.description: A method or class with too many type parameters has likely aggregated too many responsibilities and should be split.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Reduce the number of generic parameters in the '{0}' {1} to no more than the {2} authorized.

diagnostics.title: Silly bit operations should not be performed
diagnostics.description: Certain bit operations are just silly and should not be performed because their results are predictable.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this silly bit operation.

diagnostics.title: Whitespace and control characters in string literals should be explicit
diagnostics.description:
Non-encoded control characters and whitespace characters are often injected in the source code because of a bad manipulation. They are either invisible or difficult to recognize, which can result in bugs when the string is not what the developer expects. If you actually need to use a control character use their encoded version (ex: ASCII 
,	,... or Unicode U+000D, U+0009,...).
diagnostics.messageFormat: Replace the control character at position {0} by its escape sequence '{1}'.

diagnostics.title: Generic exceptions should not be ignored
diagnostics.description: When exceptions occur, it is usually a bad idea to simply ignore them. Instead, it is better to handle them properly, or at least to log them.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Handle the exception or explain in a comment why it can be ignored.

diagnostics.title: Shared resources should not be used for locking
diagnostics.description: Shared resources should not be used for locking as it increases the chance of deadlocks. Any other thread could acquire (or attempt to acquire) the same lock for another unrelated purpose.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Lock on a dedicated object instance instead.

diagnostics.title: Conditionally executed code should be reachable
diagnostics.description: Conditional expressions which are always true or false can lead to dead code. Such code is always buggy and should never be used in production.

diagnostics.title: Boolean expressions should not be gratuitous
diagnostics.description: If a boolean expression doesn't change the evaluation of the condition, then it is entirely unnecessary, and can be removed. If it is gratuitous because it does not match the programmer's intent, then it's a bug and the expression should be fixed.

diagnostics.title: The length returned from a stream read should be checked
diagnostics.description: You cannot assume that any given stream reading call will fill the byte[] passed in to the method with the number of bytes requested. Instead, you must check the value returned by the read method to see how many bytes were read. Fail to do so, and you introduce a bug that is both harmful and difficult to reproduce.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Check the return value of the '{0}' call to see how many bytes were read.

diagnostics.title: Multiline blocks should be enclosed in curly braces
diagnostics.description: Curly braces can be omitted from a one-line block, such as with an if statement or for loop, but doing so can be misleading and induce bugs.
diagnostics.messageFormat: This line will not be executed {0}; only the first line of this {2}-line block will be. The rest will execute {1}.

diagnostics.title: "NaN" should not be used in comparisons
diagnostics.description: NaN is not equal to anything, even itself. Testing for equality or inequality against NaN will yield predictable results, but probably not the ones you want.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use {0}.IsNaN() instead.

diagnostics.title: "IndexOf" checks should not be for positive numbers
diagnostics.description: Most checks against an IndexOf value compare it with -1 because 0 is a valid index. Any checks which look for values >0 ignore the first element, which is likely a bug. If the intent is merely to check inclusion of a value in a string, List, or an array, consider using the Contains method instead.
diagnostics.messageFormat: 0 is a valid index, but this check ignores it.

diagnostics.title: Instance members should not write to "static" fields
diagnostics.description: Correctly updating a static field from a non-static method is tricky to get right and could easily lead to bugs if there are multiple class instances and/or multiple threads in play.

diagnostics.title: Tests should include assertions
diagnostics.description: A test case without assertions ensures only that no exceptions are thrown. Beyond basic runnability, it ensures nothing about the behavior of the code under test.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Add at least one assertion to this test case.

diagnostics.title: Literal boolean values should not be used in assertions
diagnostics.description: There's no reason to use literal boolean values in assertions. Doing so is at best confusing for maintainers, and at worst a bug.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove or correct this assertion.

diagnostics.title: "catch" clauses should do more than rethrow
diagnostics.description: A catch clause that only rethrows the caught exception has the same effect as omitting the catch altogether and letting it bubble up automatically, but with more code and the additional detriment of leaving maintainers scratching their heads.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Add logic to this catch clause or eliminate it and rethrow the exception automatically.

diagnostics.title: Static fields should not be used in generic types
diagnostics.description: A static field in a generic type is not shared among instances of different closed constructed types, thus LengthLimitedSingletonCollection<int>.instances and LengthLimitedSingletonCollection<string>.instances will point to different objects, even though instances is seemingly shared among all LengthLimitedSingletonCollection<> generic classes.
diagnostics.messageFormat: A static field in a generic type is not shared among instances of different close constructed types.

diagnostics.title: XML parsers should not be vulnerable to XXE attacks
diagnostics.description: XML specification allows the use of entities that can be internal or external (file system / network access ...) which could lead to vulnerabilities such as confidential file disclosures or SSRFs.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Disable access to external entities in XML parsing.

diagnostics.title: "=+" should not be used instead of "+="
diagnostics.description: The use of operators pairs ( =+, =- or =! ) where the reversed, single operator was meant (+=, -= or !=) will compile and run, but not produce the expected results.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Was '{0}' meant instead?

diagnostics.title: The ternary operator should not return the same value regardless of the condition
diagnostics.description: When the second and third operands of a ternary operator are the same, the operator will always return the same value regardless of the condition. Either the operator itself is pointless, or a mistake was made in coding it.
diagnostics.messageFormat: This operation returns the same value whether the condition is 'true' or 'false'.

diagnostics.title: Sequential tests should not check the same condition
diagnostics.description: When the same condition is checked twice in a row, it is either confusing - why have separate checks? - or an error - some other condition should have been checked in the second test.
diagnostics.messageFormat: This condition was just checked on line {0}.

diagnostics.title: Doubled prefix operators "!!" and "~~" should not be used
diagnostics.description: Calling the ! or ~ prefix operator twice does nothing: the second invocation undoes the first. Such mistakes are typically caused by accidentally double-tapping the key in question without noticing.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use the '{0}' operator just once or not at all.

diagnostics.title: SQL keywords should be delimited by whitespace
diagnostics.description: Badly formed SQL is likely to cause errors at runtime.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Add a space before '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: "IDisposables" should be disposed
diagnostics.description: When writing managed code, you don't need to worry about allocating or freeing memory: The garbage collector takes care of it. For efficiency reasons, some objects such as Bitmap use unmanaged memory, enabling for example the use of pointer arithmetic. Such objects have potentially huge unmanaged memory footprints, but will have tiny managed ones. Unfortunately, the garbage collector only sees the tiny managed footprint, and fails to reclaim the unmanaged memory (by calling Bitmap's finalizer method) in a timely fashion.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Dispose '{0}' when it is no longer needed.

diagnostics.title: Classes with "IDisposable" members should implement "IDisposable"
diagnostics.description: An IDisposable object should be disposed (there are some rare exceptions where not disposing is fine, most notably Task). If a class has an IDisposable field, there can be two situations:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Implement 'IDisposable' in this class and use the 'Dispose' method to call 'Dispose' on {0}.

diagnostics.title: Fields that are only assigned in the constructor should be "readonly"
diagnostics.description: readonly fields can only be assigned in a class constructor. If a class has a field that's not marked readonly but is only set in the constructor, it could cause confusion about the field's intended use. To avoid confusion, such fields should be marked readonly to make their intended use explicit, and to prevent future maintainers from inadvertently changing their use.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make '{0}' 'readonly'.

diagnostics.title: Property assignments should not be made for "readonly" fields not constrained to reference types
diagnostics.description: While the properties of a readonly reference type field can still be changed after initialization, those of a readonly value field, such as a struct, cannot.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Restrict '{0}' to be a reference type or remove this assignment of '{1}'; it is useless if '{0}' is a value type.

diagnostics.title: Classes should "Dispose" of members from the classes' own "Dispose" methods
diagnostics.description: It is possible in an IDisposable to call Dispose on class members from any method, but the contract of Dispose is that it will clean up all unmanaged resources. Move disposing of members to some other method, and you risk resource leaks.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Move this 'Dispose' call into this class' own 'Dispose' method.

diagnostics.title: Methods named "Dispose" should implement "IDisposable.Dispose"
diagnostics.description: Dispose as a method name should be used exclusively to implement IDisposable.Dispose to prevent any confusion.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Either implement 'IDisposable.Dispose', or totally rename this method to prevent confusion.

diagnostics.title: Generic parameters not constrained to reference types should not be compared to "null"
diagnostics.description: When constraints have not been applied to restrict a generic type parameter to be a reference type, then a value type, such as a struct, could also be passed. In such cases, comparing the type parameter to null would always be false, because a struct can be empty, but never null. If a value type is truly what's expected, then the comparison should use default(). If it's not, then constraints should be added so that no value type can be passed.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use a comparison to 'default({0})' instead or add a constraint to '{0}' so that it can't be a value type.

diagnostics.title: "IEnumerable" LINQs should be simplified
diagnostics.description: In the interests of readability, code that can be simplified should be simplified. To that end, there are several ways IEnumerable language integrated queries (LINQ) can be simplified

diagnostics.title: "Object.ReferenceEquals" should not be used for value types
diagnostics.description: Using Object.ReferenceEquals to compare the references of two value types simply won't return the expected results most of the time because such types are passed by value, not by reference.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use a different kind of comparison for these value types.

diagnostics.title: "ThreadStatic" fields should not be initialized
diagnostics.description: When an object has a field annotated with ThreadStatic, that field is shared within a given thread, but unique across threads. Since a class' static initializer is only invoked for the first thread created, it also means that only the first thread will have the expected initial values.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this initialization of '{0}' or make it lazy.

diagnostics.title: "IDisposables" created in a "using" statement should not be returned
diagnostics.description: Typically you want to use using to create a local IDisposable variable; it will trigger disposal of the object when control passes out of the block's scope. The exception to this rule is when your method returns that IDisposable. In that case using disposes of the object before the caller can make use of it, likely causing exceptions at runtime. So you should either remove using or avoid returning the IDisposable.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove the 'using' statement; it will cause automatic disposal of {0}.

diagnostics.title: "ThreadStatic" should not be used on non-static fields
diagnostics.description: When a non-static class field is annotated with ThreadStatic, the code seems to show that the field can have different values for different calling threads, but that's not the case, since the ThreadStatic attribute is simply ignored on non-static fields.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove the 'ThreadStatic' attribute from this definition.

diagnostics.title: Static fields should not be updated in constructors
diagnostics.description: Assigning a value to a static field in a constructor could cause unreliable behavior at runtime since it will change the value for all instances of the class.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this assignment of '{0}' or initialize it statically.

diagnostics.title: Reflection should not be used to increase accessibility of classes, methods, or fields
diagnostics.description: This rule raises an issue when reflection is used to change the visibility of a class, method or field, and when it is used to directly update a field value. Altering or bypassing the accessibility of classes, methods, or fields violates the encapsulation principle and could lead to run-time errors.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make sure that this accessibility bypass is safe here.

diagnostics.title: Members should not be initialized to default values
diagnostics.description: The compiler automatically initializes class fields, auto-properties and events to their default values before setting them with any initialization values, so there is no need to explicitly set a member to its default value. Further, under the logic that cleaner code is better code, it's considered poor style to do so.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this initialization to '{0}', the compiler will do that for you.

diagnostics.title: "is" should not be used with "this"
diagnostics.description: There's no valid reason to test this with is. The only plausible explanation for such a test is that you're executing code in a parent class conditionally based on the kind of child class this is. But code that's specific to a child class should be in that child class, not in the parent.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Offload the code that's conditional on this 'is' test to the appropriate subclass and remove the test.

diagnostics.title: "async" methods should not return "void"
diagnostics.description: An async method with a void return type is a "fire and forget" method best reserved for event handlers because there's no way to wait for the method's execution to complete and respond accordingly. There's also no way to catch exceptions thrown from the method.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Return 'Task' instead.

diagnostics.title: Multiple "OrderBy" calls should not be used
diagnostics.description: There's no point in chaining multiple OrderBy calls in a LINQ; only the last one will be reflected in the result because each subsequent call completely reorders the list. Thus, calling OrderBy multiple times is a performance issue as well, because all of the sorting will be executed, but only the result of the last sort will be kept.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use 'ThenBy' instead.

diagnostics.title: Delegates should not be subtracted
diagnostics.description: In C#, delegates can be added together to chain their execution, and subtracted to remove their execution from the chain.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Review this subtraction of a chain of delegates: it may not work as you expect.

diagnostics.title: "interface" instances should not be cast to concrete types
diagnostics.description: Needing to cast from an interface to a concrete type indicates that something is wrong with the abstractions in use, likely that something is missing from the interface. Instead of casting to a discrete type, the missing functionality should be added to the interface. Otherwise there is a risk of runtime exceptions.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this cast and edit the interface to add the missing functionality.

diagnostics.title: "ConfigureAwait(false)" should be used
diagnostics.description: After an awaited Task has executed, you can continue execution in the original, calling thread or any arbitrary thread. Unless the rest of the code needs the context from which the Task was spawned, Task.ConfigureAwait(false) should be used to keep execution in the Task thread to avoid the need for context switching and the possibility of deadlocks.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Add '.ConfigureAwait(false)' to this call to allow execution to continue in any thread.

diagnostics.title: "Explicit" conversions of "foreach" loops should not be used
diagnostics.description: The foreach statement was introduced in the C# language prior to generics to make it easier to work with the non-generic collections available at that time such as ArrayList. The foreach statements allows you to downcast elements of a collection of Objects to any other type. The problem is that to achieve the cast, the foreach statements silently performs explicit type conversion, which at runtime can result in an InvalidCastException.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Either change the type of '{0}' to '{1}' or iterate on a generic collection of type '{2}'.

diagnostics.title: Inner class members should not shadow outer class "static" or type members
diagnostics.description: It's possible to name the members of an inner class the same as the static members of its enclosing class - possible, but a bad idea. That's because maintainers may be confused about which members are being used where. Instead the inner class' members should be renamed and all the references updated.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Rename this {0} to not shadow the outer class' member with the same name.

diagnostics.title: Method calls should not resolve ambiguously to overloads with "params"
diagnostics.description: The rules for method resolution are complex and perhaps not properly understood by all coders. The params keyword can make method declarations overlap in non-obvious ways, so that slight changes in the argument types of an invocation can resolve to different methods.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Review this call, which partially matches an overload without 'params'. The partial match is '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: "GC.SuppressFinalize" should not be invoked for types without destructors
diagnostics.description: GC.SuppressFinalize asks the Common Language Runtime not to call the finalizer of an object. This is useful when implementing the dispose pattern where object finalization is already handled in IDisposable.Dispose. However, it has no effect if there is no finalizer defined in the object's type, so using it in such cases is just confusing.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this useless call to 'GC.SuppressFinalize'.

diagnostics.title: Redundant parentheses should not be used
diagnostics.description: Redundant parentheses are simply wasted keystrokes, and should be removed.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove these redundant parentheses.

diagnostics.title: Caller information arguments should not be provided explicitly
diagnostics.description: Caller information attributes: CallerFilePathAttribute and CallerLineNumberAttribute provide a way to get information about the caller of a method through optional parameters. But the arguments for these optional parameters are only generated if they are not explicitly defined in the call. Thus, specifying the argument values defeats the purpose of the attributes.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this argument from the method call; it hides the caller information.

diagnostics.title: "value" parameters should be used
diagnostics.description: In property and indexer set methods, and in event add and remove methods, the implicit value parameter holds the value the accessor was called with. Not using the value means that the accessor ignores the caller's intent which could cause unexpected results at runtime.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use the 'value' parameter in this {0} accessor declaration.

diagnostics.title: The simplest possible condition syntax should be used
diagnostics.description: In the interests of keeping code clean, the simplest possible conditional syntax should be used. That means
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use the '{0}' operator here.

diagnostics.title: Methods should not return values that are never used
diagnostics.description: Private methods are clearly intended for use only within their own scope. When such methods return values that are never used by any of their callers, then clearly there is no need to actually make the return, and it should be removed in the interests of efficiency and clarity.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Change return type to 'void'; not a single caller uses the returned value.

diagnostics.title: Method parameters should be declared with base types
diagnostics.description: When a derived type is used as a parameter instead of the base type, it limits the uses of the method. If the additional functionality that is provided in the derived type is not requires then that limitation isn't required, and should be removed.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Consider using more general type '{0}' instead of '{1}'.

diagnostics.title: Anonymous delegates should not be used to unsubscribe from Events
diagnostics.description: It is possible to subscribe to events with anonymous delegates, but having done so, it is impossible to unsubscribe from them. That's because the process of subscribing adds the delegate to a list. The process of unsubscribing essentially says: remove this item from the subscription list. But because an anonymous delegate was used in both cases, the unsubscribe attempt tries to remove a different item from the list than was added. The result: NOOP.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Unsubscribe with the same delegate that was used for the subscription.

diagnostics.title: Generic type parameters should be co/contravariant when possible
diagnostics.description: In the interests of making code as usable as possible, interfaces and delegates with generic parameters should use the out and in modifiers when possible to make the interfaces and delegates covariant and contravariant, respectively.
