diagnostics.messageFormat: Add the '{0}' keyword to parameter '{1}' to make it '{2}'.

diagnostics.title: Duplicate casts should not be made
diagnostics.description: Because the is operator performs a cast if the object is not null, using is to check type and then casting the same argument to that type, necessarily performs two casts. The same result can be achieved more efficiently with a single cast using as, followed by a null-check.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Replace this type-check-and-cast sequence with an 'as' and a null check.

diagnostics.title: Classes directly extending "object" should not call "base" in "GetHashCode" or "Equals"
diagnostics.description: Making a base call in an overriding method is generally a good idea, but not in GetHashCode and Equals for classes that directly extend object because those methods are based on the object reference. Meaning that no two objects that use those base methods will ever be equal or have the same hash.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this 'base' call to 'object.{0}', which is directly based on the object reference.

diagnostics.title: Implementations should be provided for "partial" methods
diagnostics.description: partial methods allow an increased degree of flexibility in programming a system. Hooks can be added to generated code by invoking methods that define their signature, but might not have an implementation yet. But if the implementation is still missing when the code makes it to production, the compiler silently removes the call. In the best case scenario, such calls simply represent cruft, but in they worst case they are critical, missing functionality, the loss of which will lead to unexpected results at runtime.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Supply an implementation for {0} partial method{1}.

diagnostics.title: Constructor and destructor declarations should not be redundant
diagnostics.description: Since the compiler will automatically invoke the base type's no-argument constructor, there's no need to specify its invocation explicitly. Also, when only a single public parameterless constructor is defined in a class, then that constructor can be removed because the compiler would generate it automatically. Similarly, empty static constructors and empty destructors are also wasted keystrokes.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this redundant {0}.

diagnostics.title: Default parameter values should not be passed as arguments
diagnostics.description: Specifying the default parameter values in a method call is redundant. Such values should be omitted in the interests of readability.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this default value assigned to parameter '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: "string.IsNullOrEmpty" should be used
diagnostics.description: Using string.Equals to determine if a string is empty is significantly slower than using string.IsNullOrEmpty() or checking for string.Length == 0. string.IsNullOrEmpty() is both clear and concise, and therefore preferred to laborious, error-prone, manual null- and emptiness-checking.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use 'string.IsNullOrEmpty()' instead of comparing to empty string.

diagnostics.title: Declarations and initializations should be as concise as possible
diagnostics.description: Unnecessarily verbose declarations and initializations make it harder to read the code, and should be simplified.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove the {0}; it is redundant.

diagnostics.title: Namespaces should not be empty
diagnostics.description: Namespaces with no lines of code clutter a project and should be removed.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this empty namespace.

diagnostics.title: "params" should be used on overrides
diagnostics.description: Overriding methods automatically inherit the params behavior. To ease readability, this modifier should be explicitly used in the overriding method as well.
diagnostics.messageFormat: 'params' should not be removed from an override.

diagnostics.title: Static fields should appear in the order they must be initialized
diagnostics.description: Static field initializers are executed in the order in which they appear in the class from top to bottom. Thus, placing a static field in a class above the field or fields required for its initialization will yield unexpected results.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Move this field's initializer into a static constructor.

diagnostics.title: Events should be invoked
diagnostics.description: Events that are not invoked anywhere are dead code, and there's no good reason to keep them in the source.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove the unused event '{0}' or invoke it.

diagnostics.title: Non-flags enums should not be used in bitwise operations
diagnostics.description: enums are usually used to identify distinct elements in a set of values. However enums can be treated as bit fields and bitwise operations can be used on them to combine the values. This is a good way of specifying multiple elements of set with a single value. When enums are used this way, it is a best practice to mark the enum with the FlagsAttribute.

diagnostics.title: Cipher Block Chaining IV's should be random and unique
diagnostics.description: In encryption, when Cipher Block Chaining (CBC) is used, the Initialization Vector (IV) must be random and unpredictable. Otherwise, the encrypted value is vulnerable to crypto-analysis attacks such as the "Chosen-Plaintext Attack".
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use a dynamically-generated, random IV.

diagnostics.title: Creating cookies without the "HttpOnly" flag is security-sensitive
diagnostics.description: When a cookie is configured with the HttpOnly attribute set to true, the browser guaranties that no client-side script will be able to read it. In most cases, when a cookie is created, the default value of HttpOnly is false and it's up to the developer to decide whether or not the content of the cookie can be read by the client-side script. As a majority of Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks target the theft of session-cookies, the HttpOnly attribute can help to reduce their impact as it won't be possible to exploit the XSS vulnerability to steal session-cookies.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make sure creating this cookie without the "HttpOnly" flag is safe.

diagnostics.title: Caller information parameters should come at the end of the parameter list
diagnostics.description: Caller information attributes (CallerFilePathAttribute, CallerLineNumberAttribute, and CallerMemberNameAttribute) provide a way to get information about the caller of a method through optional parameters. But they only work right if their values aren't provided explicitly. So if you define a method with caller info attributes in the middle of the parameter list, you put your callers in a bad position: they are forced to use named arguments if they want to use the method properly.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Move '{0}' to the end of the parameter list.

diagnostics.title: Expressions used in "Debug.Assert" should not produce side effects
diagnostics.description: An assertion is a piece of code that's used during development when the compilation debug mode is activated. It allows a program to check itself as it runs. When an assertion is true, that means everything is operating as expected.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Expressions used in 'Debug.Assert' should not produce side effects.

diagnostics.title: Unchanged local variables should be "const"
diagnostics.description: Marking a variable that is unchanged after initialization const is an indication to future maintainers that "no this isn't updated, and it's not supposed to be". const should be used in these situations in the interests of code clarity.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Add the 'const' modifier to '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: Ternary operators should not be nested
diagnostics.description: Just because you can do something, doesn't mean you should, and that's the case with nested ternary operations. Nesting ternary operators results in the kind of code that may seem clear as day when you write it, but six months later will leave maintainers (or worse - future you) scratching their heads and cursing.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Extract this nested ternary operation into an independent statement.

diagnostics.title: "this" should not be exposed from constructors
diagnostics.description: In single-threaded environments, the use of this in constructors is normal, and expected. But in multi-threaded environments, it could expose partially-constructed objects to other threads, and should be used with caution.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make sure the use of 'this' doesn't expose partially-constructed instances of this class in multi-threaded environments.

diagnostics.title: Attribute, EventArgs, and Exception type names should end with the type being extended
diagnostics.description: Adherence to the standard naming conventions makes your code not only more readable, but more usable. For instance, class FirstAttribute : Attribute can be used simply with First, but you must use the full name for class AttributeOne : Attribute.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make this class name end with '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: "base.Equals" should not be used to check for reference equality in "Equals" if "base" is not "object"
diagnostics.description: object.Equals() overrides can be optimized by checking first for reference equality between this and the parameter. This check can be implemented by calling object.ReferenceEquals() or base.Equals(), where base is object. However, using base.Equals() is a maintenance hazard because while it works if you extend Object directly, if you introduce a new base class that overrides Equals, it suddenly stops working.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Change this guard condition to call 'object.ReferenceEquals'.

diagnostics.title: Methods should not return constants
diagnostics.description: There's no point in forcing the overhead of a method call for a method that always returns the same constant value. Even worse, the fact that a method call must be made will likely mislead developers who call the method thinking that something more is done. Declare a constant instead.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this method and declare a constant for this value.

diagnostics.title: Assertion arguments should be passed in the correct order
diagnostics.description: The standard assertions library methods such as AreEqual and AreSame in MSTest and NUnit, or Equal and Same in XUnit, expect the first argument to be the expected value and the second argument to be the actual value. Swap them, and your test will still have the same outcome (succeed/fail when it should) but the error messages will be confusing.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make sure these 2 arguments are in the correct order: expected value, actual value.

diagnostics.title: Method overloads with default parameter values should not overlap
diagnostics.description: The rules for method resolution are complex and perhaps not properly understood by all coders. Having overloads with optional parameter values makes the matter even harder to understand.
diagnostics.messageFormat: This method signature overlaps the one defined on line {0}{1}, the default parameter value {2}.

diagnostics.title: "[ExpectedException]" should not be used
diagnostics.description: It should be clear to a casual reader what code a test is testing and what results are expected. Unfortunately, that's not usually the case with the [ExpectedException] attribute since an exception could be thrown from almost any line in the method.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Replace the 'ExpectedException' attribute with a try/catch block.

diagnostics.title: Test method signatures should be correct
diagnostics.description: A method is detected as test method if marked with one of the following attributes [TestMethod] or [DataTestMethod] (for mstest), [Fact] or [Theory] (for xunit) or [Test], [TestCase], [TestCaseSource] or [Theory] (for nunit). However, whether or not they have a test attribute, non-public methods are not recognized as tests, and therefore not executed. Neither are async void methods, or methods with generics anywhere in their signatures.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make this test method {0}.

diagnostics.title: Variables should not be checked against the values they're about to be assigned
diagnostics.description: There's no point in checking a variable against the value you're about to assign it. Save the cycles and lines of code, and simply perform the assignment.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this useless conditional.

diagnostics.title: Redundant property names should be omitted in anonymous classes
diagnostics.description: When an anonymous type's properties are copied from properties or variables with the same names, it yields cleaner code to omit the new type's property name and the assignment operator.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove the redundant '{0} ='.

diagnostics.title: "abstract" classes should not have "public" constructors
diagnostics.description: Since abstract classes can't be instantiated, there's no point in their having public or internal constructors. If there is basic initialization logic that should run when an extending class instance is created, you can by all means put it in a constructor, but make that constructor private or protected.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Change the visibility of this constructor to 'protected'.

diagnostics.title: Type should not be examined on "System.Type" instances
diagnostics.description: If you call GetType() on a Type variable, the return value will always be typeof(System.Type). So there's no real point in making that call. The same applies to passing a type argument to IsInstanceOfType. In both cases the results are entirely predictable.

diagnostics.title: Interfaces should not simply inherit from base interfaces with colliding members
diagnostics.description: When an interface inherits from two interfaces that both define a member with the same name, trying to access that member through the derived interface will result in the compiler error CS0229 Ambiguity between 'IBase1.SomeProperty' and 'IBase2.SomeProperty'.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Rename or add member{1} {0} to this interface to resolve ambiguities.

diagnostics.title: Exceptions should not be explicitly rethrown
diagnostics.description: When rethrowing an exception, you should do it by simply calling throw; and not throw exc;, because the stack trace is reset with the second syntax, making debugging a lot harder.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Consider using 'throw;' to preserve the stack trace.

diagnostics.title: "[Optional]" should not be used on "ref" or "out" parameters
diagnostics.description: The use of ref or out in combination with [Optional] is both confusing and contradictory. [Optional] indicates that the parameter doesn't have to be provided, while out and ref mean that the parameter will be used to return data to the caller (ref additionally indicates that the parameter may also be used to pass data into the method).
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove the 'Optional' attribute, it cannot be used with '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: Right operands of shift operators should be integers
diagnostics.description: Numbers can be shifted with the << and >> operators, but the right operand of the operation needs to be an int or a type that has an implicit conversion to int. However, with dynamic, the compiler's type checking is turned off, so you can pass anything to a shift operator and have it compile. And if the argument can't be converted to int at runtime, then a RuntimeBinderException will be raised.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this erroneous shift, it will fail because '{0}' can't be implicitly converted to 'int'.

diagnostics.title: Parameters with "[DefaultParameterValue]" attributes should also be marked "[Optional]"
diagnostics.description: There is no point in providing a default value for a parameter if callers are required to provide a value for it anyway. Thus, [DefaultParameterValue] should always be used in conjunction with [Optional].
diagnostics.messageFormat: Add the 'Optional' attribute to this parameter.

diagnostics.title: "[DefaultValue]" should not be used when "[DefaultParameterValue]" is meant
diagnostics.description: The use of [DefaultValue] with [Optional] has no more effect than [Optional] alone. That's because [DefaultValue] doesn't actually do anything; it merely indicates the intent for the value. More than likely, [DefaultValue] was used in confusion instead of [DefaultParameterValue].
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use '[DefaultParameterValue]' instead.

diagnostics.title: Classes should not have only "private" constructors
diagnostics.description: A class with only private constructors can't be instantiated, thus, it seems to be pointless code.
diagnostics.messageFormat: This class can't be instantiated; make {0} 'public'.

diagnostics.title: "string.ToCharArray()" should not be called redundantly
diagnostics.description: ToCharArray can be omitted when the operation on the array could have been done directly on the string, such as when iterating over the characters in a string, and when accessing a character in a string via an array index. In those cases, explicit ToCharArray calls should be omitted.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this redundant 'ToCharArray' call.

diagnostics.title: Composite format strings should be used correctly
diagnostics.description: Because composite format strings are interpreted at runtime, rather than validated by the compiler, they can contain errors that lead to unexpected behaviors or runtime errors. This rule statically validates the good behavior of composite formats when calling the methods of String.Format, StringBuilder.AppendFormat, Console.Write, Console.WriteLine, TextWriter.Write, TextWriter.WriteLine, Debug.WriteLine(String,Object[]), Trace.TraceError(String,Object[]), Trace.TraceInformation(String,Object[]), Trace.TraceWarning(String,Object[]) and TraceSource.TraceInformation(String,Object[]).

diagnostics.title: Empty "case" clauses that fall through to the "default" should be omitted
diagnostics.description: Empty case clauses that fall through to the default are useless. Whether or not such a case is present, the default clause will be invoked. Such cases simply clutter the code, and should be removed.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this empty 'case' clause.

diagnostics.title: Unassigned members should be removed
diagnostics.description: Fields and auto-properties that are never assigned to hold the default values for their types. They are either pointless code or, more likely, mistakes.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove unassigned {0} '{1}', or set its value.

diagnostics.title: Type inheritance should not be recursive
diagnostics.description: Recursion is acceptable in methods, where you can break out of it. But with class types, you end up with code that will compile but not run if you try to instantiate the class.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor this {0} so that the generic inheritance chain is not recursive.

diagnostics.title: Optional parameters should be passed to "base" calls
diagnostics.description: Generally, writing the least code that will readably do the job is a good thing, so omitting default parameter values seems to make sense. Unfortunately, when you omit them from the base call in an override, you're not actually getting the job done thoroughly, because you're ignoring the value the caller passed in. The result will likely not be what the caller expected.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Pass the missing user-supplied parameter value{0} to this 'base' call.

diagnostics.title: Empty "default" clauses should be removed
diagnostics.description: The default clause should take appropriate action. Having an empty default is a waste of keystrokes.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this empty 'default' clause.

diagnostics.title: "ServiceContract" and "OperationContract" attributes should be used together
diagnostics.description: The ServiceContract attribute specifies that a class or interface defines the communication contract of a Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) service. The service operations of this class or interface are defined by OperationContract attributes added to methods. It doesn't make sense to define a contract without any service operations; thus, in a ServiceContract class or interface at least one method should be annotated with OperationContract. Similarly, WCF only serves OperationContract methods that are defined inside ServiceContract classes or interfaces; thus, this rule also checks that ServiceContract is added to the containing type of OperationContract methods.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Add the '{0}' attribute to {1}.

diagnostics.title: One-way "OperationContract" methods should have "void" return type
diagnostics.description: When declaring a Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) OperationContract method one-way, that service method won't return any result, not even an underlying empty confirmation message. These are fire-and-forget methods that are useful in event-like communication. Specifying a return type therefore does not make sense.
diagnostics.messageFormat: This method can't return any values because it is marked as one-way operation.

diagnostics.title: "params" should not be introduced on overrides
diagnostics.description: Adding params to a method override has no effect. The compiler accepts it, but the callers won't be able to benefit from the added modifier.
diagnostics.messageFormat: 'params' should be removed from this override.

diagnostics.title: Methods with "Pure" attribute should return a value
diagnostics.description: Marking a method with the Pure attribute specifies that the method doesn't make any visible changes; thus, the method should return a result, otherwise the call to the method should be equal to no-operation. So Pure on a void method is either a mistake, or the method doesn't do any meaningful task.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove the 'Pure' attribute or change the method to return a value.

diagnostics.title: Member initializer values should not be redundant
diagnostics.description: Fields, properties and events can be initialized either inline or in the constructor. Initializing them inline and in the constructor at the same time is redundant; the inline initialization will be overridden.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove the member initializer, all constructors set an initial value for the member.

diagnostics.title: Nullable type comparison should not be redundant
diagnostics.description: Calling GetType() on a nullable object returns the underlying value type. Thus, comparing the returned Type object to typeof(Nullable<SomeType>) doesn't make sense. The comparison either throws an exception or the result can be known at compile time.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this redundant type comparison.

diagnostics.title: Jump statements should not be redundant
diagnostics.description: Jump statements, such as return, yield break, goto, and continue let you change the default flow of program execution, but jump statements that direct the control flow to the original direction are just a waste of keystrokes.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this redundant jump.

diagnostics.title: Empty nullable value should not be accessed
diagnostics.description: Nullable value types can hold either a value or null. The value held in the nullable type can be accessed with the Value property, but .Value throws an InvalidOperationException when the value is null. To avoid the exception, a nullable type should always be tested before .Value is accessed.
diagnostics.messageFormat: '{0}' is null on at least one execution path.

diagnostics.title: Exception constructors should not throw exceptions
diagnostics.description: It may be a good idea to raise an exception in a constructor if you're unable to fully flesh the object in question, but not in an exception constructor. If you do, you'll interfere with the exception that was originally being thrown. Further, it is highly unlikely that an exception raised in the creation of an exception will be properly handled in the calling code, and the unexpected, unhandled exception will lead to program termination.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Avoid throwing exceptions in this constructor.

diagnostics.title: Track use of "NotImplementedException"
diagnostics.description: NotImplementedException is often used to mark methods which must be implemented for the overall functionality to be complete, but which the developer wants to implement later. That's as opposed to the NotSupportedException which is thrown by methods which are required by base classes or interfaces, but which are not appropriate to the current class.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Implement this method or throw 'NotSupportedException' instead.

diagnostics.title: Cognitive Complexity of methods should not be too high
diagnostics.description: Cognitive Complexity is a measure of how hard the control flow of a method is to understand. Methods with high Cognitive Complexity will be difficult to maintain.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor this {0} to reduce its Cognitive Complexity from {1} to the {2} allowed.

diagnostics.title: "SafeHandle.DangerousGetHandle" should not be called
diagnostics.description: Not surprisingly, the SafeHandle.DangerousGetHandle method is dangerous. That's because it may not return a valid handle. Using it can lead to leaks and vulnerabilities. While it is possible to use the method successfully, it's extremely difficult to do correctly, so the method should simply be avoided altogether.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor the code to remove this use of '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: Exception types should be "public"
diagnostics.description: The point of having custom exception types is to convey more information than is available in standard types. But custom exception types must be public for that to work.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make this exception 'public'.

diagnostics.title: Parameter names should not duplicate the names of their methods
diagnostics.description: The name of a method should communicate what it does, and the names of its parameters should indicate how they're used. If a method and its parameter have the same name it is an indication that one of these rules of thumb has been broken, if not both. Even if by some trick of language that's not the case, it is still likely to confuse callers and maintainers.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Rename the parameter '{0}' so that it does not duplicate the method name.

diagnostics.title: "out" and "ref" parameters should not be used
diagnostics.description: Passing a parameter by reference, which is what happens when you use the out or ref parameter modifiers, means that the method will receive a pointer to the argument, rather than the argument itself. If the argument was a value type, the method will be able to change the argument's values. If it was a reference type, then the method receives a pointer to a pointer, which is usually not what was intended. Even when it is what was intended, this is the sort of thing that's difficult to get right, and should be used with caution.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Consider refactoring this method in order to remove the need for this '{0}' modifier.

diagnostics.title: "operator==" should not be overloaded on reference types
diagnostics.description: The use of == to compare to objects is expected to do a reference comparison. That is, it is expected to return true if and only if they are the same object instance. Overloading the operator to do anything else will inevitably lead to the introduction of bugs by callers. On the other hand, overloading it to do exactly that is pointless; that's what == does by default.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this overload of 'operator =='.

diagnostics.title: Strings or integral types should be used for indexers
diagnostics.description: Strings and integral types are typically used as indexers. When some other type is required, it typically indicates design problems, and potentially a situation where a method should be used instead.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use string or an integral type here, or refactor this indexer into a method.

diagnostics.title: Exceptions should not be thrown from unexpected methods
diagnostics.description: It is expected that some methods should be called with caution, but others, such as ToString, are expected to "just work". Throwing an exception from such a method is likely to break callers' code unexpectedly.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this 'throw' statement.

diagnostics.title: Finalizers should not be empty
diagnostics.description: Finalizers come with a performance cost due to the overhead of tracking the life cycle of objects. An empty one is consequently costly with no benefit or justification.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this empty finalizer.

diagnostics.title: "IDisposable" should be implemented correctly
diagnostics.description: The IDisposable interface is a mechanism to release unmanaged resources, if not implemented correctly this could result in resource leaks or more severe bugs.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Fix this implementation of 'IDisposable' to conform to the dispose pattern.

diagnostics.title: "CoSetProxyBlanket" and "CoInitializeSecurity" should not be used
diagnostics.description: CoSetProxyBlanket and CoInitializeSecurity both work to set the permissions context in which the process invoked immediately after is executed. Calling them from within that process is useless because it's too late at that point; the permissions context has already been set.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor the code to remove this use of '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: "Assembly.Load" should be used
diagnostics.description: The parameter to Assembly.Load includes the full specification of the dll to be loaded. Use another method, and you might end up with a dll other than the one you expected.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Replace this call to '{0}' with 'Assembly.Load'.

diagnostics.title: Mutable, non-private fields should not be "readonly"
diagnostics.description: Using the readonly keyword on a field means that it can't be changed after initialization. However, when applied to collections or arrays, that's only partly true. readonly enforces that another instance can't be assigned to the field, but it cannot keep the contents from being updated. That means that in practice, the field value really can be changed, and the use of readonly on such a field is misleading, and you're likely to not be getting the behavior you expect.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use an immutable collection or reduce the accessibility of the field(s) {0}.

diagnostics.title: Neither "Thread.Resume" nor "Thread.Suspend" should be used
diagnostics.description: Thread.Suspend and Thread.Resume can give unpredictable results, and both methods have been deprecated. Indeed, if Thread.Suspend is not used very carefully, a thread can be suspended while holding a lock, thus leading to a deadlock. Other safer synchronization mechanisms should be used, such as Monitor, Mutex, and Semaphore.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor the code to remove this use of '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: Classes that provide "Equals(<T>)" should implement "IEquatable<T>"
diagnostics.description: The IEquatable<T> interface has only one method in it: Equals(<T>). If you've already written Equals(T), there's no reason not to explicitly implement IEquatable<T>. Doing so expands the utility of your class by allowing it to be used where an IEquatable is called for.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Implement 'IEquatable<{0}>'.

diagnostics.title: Value types should implement "IEquatable<T>"
diagnostics.description: If you're using a struct, it is likely because you're interested in performance. But by failing to implement IEquatable<T> you're loosing performance when comparisons are made because without IEquatable<T>, boxing and reflection are used to make comparisons.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Implement 'IEquatable<T>' in value type '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: Arguments of public methods should be validated against null
diagnostics.description: A publicly accessible method can be called from anywhere, which means you should validate parameters to be within the expected constraints. In general, checking against null is recommended defensive programming.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor this {0}.

diagnostics.title: "Assembly.GetExecutingAssembly" should not be called
diagnostics.description: Using Type.Assembly to get the current assembly is nearly free in terms of performance; it's a simple property access. On the other hand, Assembly.GetExecutingAssembly() can take up to 30 times as long because it walks up the call stack to find the assembly.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Replace this call to 'Assembly.GetExecutingAssembly()' with 'Type.Assembly'.

diagnostics.title: Types should be defined in named namespaces
diagnostics.description: Types are declared in namespaces in order to prevent name collisions and as a way to organize them into the object hierarchy. Types that are defined outside any named namespace are in a global namespace that cannot be referenced in code.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Move '{0}' into a named namespace.

diagnostics.title: Assemblies should have version information
diagnostics.description: If no AssemblyVersionAttribute is provided, the same default version will be used for every build. Since the version number is used by The .NET Framework to uniquely identify an assembly this can lead to broken dependencies.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Provide an 'AssemblyVersion' attribute for assembly '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: Event Handlers should have the correct signature
diagnostics.description: Delegate event handlers (i.e. delegates used as type of an event) should have a very specific signature:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Change the signature of that event handler to match the specified signature.

diagnostics.title: Generic event handlers should be used
diagnostics.description: Since .Net Framework version 2.0 it is not necessary to declare a delegate that specifies a class derived from System.EventArgs. The System.EventHandler<TEventArgs> delegate mechanism should be used instead as it allows any class derived from EventArgs to be used with that handler.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor this delegate to use 'System.EventHandler<TEventArgs>'.

diagnostics.title: Collections should implement the generic interface
diagnostics.description: The NET Framework 2.0 introduced the generic interface System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable<T> and it should be preferred over the older, non generic, interfaces.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor this collection to implement '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: All branches in a conditional structure should not have exactly the same implementation
diagnostics.description: Having all branches in a switch or if chain with the same implementation is an error. Either a copy-paste error was made and something different should be executed, or there shouldn't be a switch/if chain at all.

diagnostics.title: "ISerializable" should be implemented correctly
diagnostics.description: The ISerializable interface is the mechanism to control the type serialization process. If not implemented correctly this could result in an invalid serialization and hard to detect bugs.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Update this implementation of 'ISerializable' to conform to the recommended serialization pattern.

diagnostics.title: Deserialization methods should be provided for "OptionalField" members
diagnostics.description: Fields marked with System.Runtime.Serialization.OptionalFieldAttribute are serialized just like any other field. But such fields are ignored on deserialization, and retain the default values associated with their types. Therefore, deserialization event handlers should be declared to set such fields during the deserialization process.

diagnostics.title: Serialization event handlers should be implemented correctly
diagnostics.description: Serialization event handlers that don't have the correct signature will simply not be called, thus bypassing any attempts to augment the automated de/serialization.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make this method {0}.

diagnostics.title: Parameter names used into ArgumentException constructors should match an existing one
diagnostics.description: Some constructors of the ArgumentException, ArgumentNullException, ArgumentOutOfRangeException and DuplicateWaitObjectException classes must be fed with a valid parameter name. This rule raises an issue in two cases:

diagnostics.title: Number patterns should be regular
diagnostics.description: The use of punctuation characters to separate subgroups in a number can make the number more readable. For instance consider 1,000,000,000 versus 1000000000. But when the grouping is irregular, such as 1,000,00,000; it indicates an error.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Review this number; its irregular pattern indicates an error.

diagnostics.title: Calculations should not overflow
diagnostics.description: Numbers are infinite, but the types that hold them are not. Each numeric type has hard upper and lower bounds. Try to calculate or assign numbers beyond those bounds, and the result will be a value that has silently wrapped around from the expected positive value to a negative one, or vice versa.

diagnostics.title: "Generic.List" instances should not be part of public APIs
diagnostics.description: System.Collections.Generic.List<T> is a generic collection that is designed for performance and not inheritance. For example, it does not contain virtual members that make it easier to change the behavior of an inherited class. That means that future attempts to expand the behavior will be spoiled because the extension points simply aren't there. Instead, one of the following generic collections should be used:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor this {0} to use a generic collection designed for inheritance.

diagnostics.title: "static readonly" constants should be "const" instead
diagnostics.description: The value of a static readonly field is computed at runtime while the value of a const field is calculated at compile time, which improves performance.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Replace this 'static readonly' declaration with 'const'.

diagnostics.title: "static" fields should be initialized inline
diagnostics.description: When a static constructor serves no other purpose that initializing static fields, it comes with an unnecessary performance cost because the compiler generates a check before each static method or instance constructor invocation.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Initialize all 'static fields' inline and remove the 'static constructor'.

diagnostics.title: Objects should not be disposed more than once
diagnostics.description: Disposing an object twice, either with the using keyword or by calling Dispose directly, in the same method is at best confusing and at worst error-prone. The next developer might see only one of the Dispose/using and try to use an already-disposed object.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor this code to make sure '{0}' is disposed only once.

diagnostics.title: Multidimensional arrays should not be used
diagnostics.description: A jagged array is an array whose elements are arrays. It is recommended over a multidimensional array because the arrays that make up the elements can be of different sizes, which avoids wasting memory space.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Change this multidimensional array to a jagged array.

diagnostics.title: "GC.SuppressFinalize" should not be called
diagnostics.description: GC.SuppressFinalize requests that the system not call the finalizer for the specified object. This should only be done when implementing Dispose as part of the Dispose Pattern.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Do not call 'GC.SuppressFinalize'.

diagnostics.title: Conditionals should start on new lines
diagnostics.description: Code is clearest when each statement has its own line. Nonetheless, it is a common pattern to combine on the same line an if and its resulting then statement. However, when an if is placed on the same line as the closing } from a preceding then, else or else if part, it is either an error - else is missing - or the invitation to a future error as maintainers fail to understand that the two statements are unconnected.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Move this 'if' to a new line or add the missing 'else'.

diagnostics.title: A conditionally executed single line should be denoted by indentation
diagnostics.description: In the absence of enclosing curly braces, the line immediately after a conditional is the one that is conditionally executed. By both convention and good practice, such lines are indented. In the absence of both curly braces and indentation the intent of the original programmer is entirely unclear and perhaps not actually what is executed. Additionally, such code is highly likely to be confusing to maintainers.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use curly braces or indentation to denote the code conditionally executed by this '{0}'

diagnostics.title: Collection sizes and array length comparisons should make sense
diagnostics.description: The size of a collection and the length of an array are always greater than or equal to zero. So testing that a size or length is greater than or equal to zero doesn't make sense, since the result is always true. Similarly testing that it is less than zero will always return false. Perhaps the intent was to check the non-emptiness of the collection or array instead.
diagnostics.messageFormat: The {0} of '{1}' is always '>=0', so fix this test to get the real expected behavior.

diagnostics.title: Exceptions should not be created without being thrown
diagnostics.description: Creating a new Exception without actually throwing it is useless and is probably due to a mistake.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Throw this exception or remove this useless statement.

diagnostics.title: Assemblies should be marked as CLS compliant
diagnostics.description: Assemblies should conform with the Common Language Specification (CLS) in order to be usable across programming languages. To be compliant an assembly has to indicate it with System.CLSCompliantAttribute.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Provide a 'CLSCompliant' attribute for assembly '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: Assemblies should explicitly specify COM visibility
diagnostics.description: Assemblies should explicitly indicate whether they are meant to be COM visible or not. If the ComVisibleAttribute is not present, the default is to make the content of the assembly visible to COM clients.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Provide a 'ComVisible' attribute for assembly '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: Custom attributes should be marked with "System.AttributeUsageAttribute"
diagnostics.description: When defining custom attributes, System.AttributeUsageAttribute must be used to indicate where the attribute can be applied. This will determine its valid locations in the code.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Specify AttributeUsage on '{0}'{1}.

diagnostics.title: URI Parameters should not be strings
diagnostics.description: String representations of URIs or URLs are prone to parsing and encoding errors which can lead to vulnerabilities. The System.Uri class is a safe alternative and should be preferred. At minimum, an overload of the method taking a System.Uri as a parameter should be provided in each class that contains a method with an apparent Uri passed as a string.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Either change this parameter type to 'System.Uri' or provide an overload which takes a 'System.Uri' parameter.

diagnostics.title: URI return values should not be strings
diagnostics.description: String representations of URIs or URLs are prone to parsing and encoding errors which can lead to vulnerabilities. The System.Uri class is a safe alternative and should be preferred.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Change this return type to 'System.Uri'.

diagnostics.title: URI properties should not be strings
diagnostics.description: String representations of URIs or URLs are prone to parsing and encoding errors which can lead to vulnerabilities. The System.Uri class is a safe alternative and should be preferred.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Change this property type to 'System.Uri'.

diagnostics.title: String URI overloads should call "System.Uri" overloads
diagnostics.description: String representations of URIs or URLs are prone to parsing and encoding errors which can lead to vulnerabilities. The System.Uri class is a safe alternative and should be preferred.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor this method so it invokes the overload accepting a 'System.Uri' parameter.

diagnostics.title: Threads should not lock on objects with weak identity
diagnostics.description: A thread acquiring a lock on an object that can be accessed across application domain boundaries runs the risk of being blocked by another thread in a different application domain. Objects that can be accessed across application domain boundaries are said to have weak identity. Types with weak identity are:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Replace this lock on '{0}' with a lock against an object that cannot be accessed across application domain boundaries.

diagnostics.title: Pointers to unmanaged memory should not be visible
diagnostics.description: The IntPtr and UIntPtr types are used to access unmanaged memory, usually in order to use C or C++ libraries. If such a pointer is not secured by making it private, internal or readonly, it can lead to a vulnerability allowing access to arbitrary locations.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make '{0}' 'private' or 'protected readonly'.

diagnostics.title: Disposable types should declare finalizers
diagnostics.description: This rule raises an issue when a disposable type contains fields of the following types and does not implement a finalizer:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Implement a finalizer that calls your 'Dispose' method.

diagnostics.title: Collection properties should be readonly
diagnostics.description: A writable collection property can be replaced by a completely different collection. Making it readonly prevents that while still allowing individual members to be set. If you want to allow the replacement of the whole collection the recommended pattern is to implement a method to remove all the elements (e.g. System.Collections.List<T>.Clear) and a method to populate the collection (e.g. System.Collections.List<T>.AddRange).
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make the '{0}' property read-only by removing the property setter or making it private.

diagnostics.title: "System.Uri" arguments should be used instead of strings
diagnostics.description: String representations of URIs or URLs are prone to parsing and encoding errors which can lead to vulnerabilities. The System.Uri class is a safe alternative and should be preferred.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Call the overload that takes a 'System.Uri' as an argument instead.

diagnostics.title: Inherited member visibility should not be decreased
diagnostics.description: Changing an inherited member to private will not prevent access to the base class implementation.
diagnostics.messageFormat: This member hides '{0}'. Make it non-private or seal the class.

diagnostics.title: Enumeration members should not be named "Reserved"
diagnostics.description: If an enum member's name contains the word "reserved" it implies it is not currently used and will be change in the future. However changing an enum member is a breaking change and can create significant problems. There is no need to reserve an enum member since a new member can be added in the future, and such an addition will usually not be a breaking change.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove or rename this enum member.

diagnostics.title: Method signatures should not contain nested generic types
diagnostics.description: A nested type is a type argument that is also a generic type. Calling a method with such a nested type argument requires complicated and confusing code. It should be avoided as much as possible.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor this method to remove the nested type argument.

diagnostics.title: Generic methods should provide type parameters
diagnostics.description: The best way to determine the type of a generic method is by inference based on the type of argument that is passed to the method. This is not possible when a parameter type is missing from the argument list.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor this method to have parameters matching all the type parameters.

diagnostics.title: Base class methods should not be hidden
diagnostics.description: When a method in a derived class has the same name as a method in the base class but with a signature that only differs by types that are weakly derived (e.g. object vs string), the result is that the base method becomes hidden.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove or rename that method because it hides '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: Enumerations should have "Int32" storage
diagnostics.description: By default the storage type of an enum is Int32. In most cases it is not necessary to change this. In particular you will not achieve any performance gain by using a smaller data type (e.g. Byte) and may limit future uses.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Change this enum storage to 'Int32'.

diagnostics.title: Interfaces should not be empty
diagnostics.description: Empty interfaces are usually used as a marker or a way to identify groups of types. The preferred way to achieve this is to use custom attributes.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this interface or add members to it.

diagnostics.title: Child class fields should not differ from parent class fields only by capitalization
diagnostics.description: Having a field in a child class with a name that differs from a parent class' field only by capitalization is sure to cause confusion. Such child class fields should be renamed.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Rename this field; it may be confused with '{0}' in '{1}'.

diagnostics.title: Assemblies should be marked with "NeutralResourcesLanguageAttribute"
diagnostics.description: It is important to inform the ResourceManager of the language used to display the resources of the neutral culture for an assembly. This improves lookup performance for the first resource loaded.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Mark this assembly with 'System.Resources.NeutralResourcesLanguageAttribute'.

diagnostics.title: Exceptions should provide standard constructors
diagnostics.description: Exceptions types should provide the following constructors:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Implement the missing constructors for this exception.

diagnostics.title: Classes implementing "IEquatable<T>" should be sealed
diagnostics.description: When a class implements the IEquatable<T> interface, it enters a contract that, in effect, states "I know how to compare two instances of type T or any type derived from T for equality.". However if that class is derived, it is very unlikely that the base class will know how to make a meaningful comparison. Therefore that implicit contract is now broken.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Seal class '{0}' or implement 'IEqualityComparer<T>' instead.

diagnostics.title: Interface methods should be callable by derived types
diagnostics.description: When a base type explicitly implements a public interface method, that method is only accessible in derived types through a reference to the current instance (namely this). If the derived type explicitly overrides that interface method, the base implementation becomes inaccessible.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make '{0}' sealed, change to a non-explicit declaration or provide a new method exposing the functionality of '{1}'.

diagnostics.title: Strings should be normalized to uppercase
diagnostics.description: Certain characters, once normalized to lowercase, cannot make a round trip. That is, they can not be converted from one locale to another and then accurately restored to their original characters.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Change this normalization to 'ToUpperInvariant()'.

diagnostics.title: Type names should not match namespaces
diagnostics.description: When a type name matches the name of a publicly defined namespace, for instance one in the .NET framework class library, it leads to confusion and makes the library that much harder to use.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Change the name of type '{0}' to be different from an existing framework namespace.

diagnostics.title: Generics should be used when appropriate
diagnostics.description: When a reference parameter (keyword ref) is used, the passed argument type must exactly match the reference parameter type. This means that to be able to pass a derived type, it must be cast and assigned to a variable of the proper type. Use of generic methods eliminates that cumbersome down casting and should therefore be preferred.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make this method generic and replace the 'object' parameter with a type parameter.

diagnostics.title: Properties should be preferred
diagnostics.description: Properties are accessed like fields which makes them easier to use.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Consider making method '{0}' a property.

diagnostics.title: Operators should be overloaded consistently
diagnostics.description: When implementing operator overloads, it is very important to make sure that all related operators and methods are consistent in their implementation.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Provide an implementation for: {0}.

diagnostics.title: Types should not extend outdated base types
diagnostics.description: With the advent of .NET framework version 2, certain practices have become obsolete.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor this type not to derive from an outdated type '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: Literals should not be passed as localized parameters
diagnostics.description: String literals embedded in the source code will not be localized properly.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Replace this string literal with a string retrieved through an instance of the 'ResourceManager' class.

diagnostics.title: Overloads with a "CultureInfo" or an "IFormatProvider" parameter should be used
diagnostics.description: When a System.Globalization.CultureInfo or IFormatProvider object is not supplied, the default value that is supplied by the overloaded member might not have the effect that you want in all locales.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use the overload that takes a 'CultureInfo' or 'IFormatProvider' parameter.

diagnostics.title: Locales should be set for data types
diagnostics.description: When you create a DataTable or DataSet, you should set the locale explicitly. By default, the locale for these types is the current culture. For data that is stored in a database or file and is shared globally, the locale should ordinarily be set to the invariant culture (CultureInfo.InvariantCulture).
diagnostics.messageFormat: Set the locale for this '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: Overloads with a "StringComparison" parameter should be used
diagnostics.description: Many string operations, the Compare and Equals methods in particular, provide an overload that accepts a StringComparison enumeration value as a parameter. Calling these overloads and explicitly providing this parameter makes your code clearer and easier to maintain.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Change this call to '{0}' to an overload that accepts a 'StringComparison' as a parameter.

diagnostics.title: Property names should not match get methods
diagnostics.description: Properties and Get method should have names that makes them clearly distinguishable.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Change either the name of property '{0}' or the name of method '{1}' to make them distinguishable.

diagnostics.title: Non-abstract attributes should be sealed
diagnostics.description: The .NET framework class library provides methods for retrieving custom attributes. Sealing the attribute eliminates the search through the inheritance hierarchy, and can improve performance.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Seal this attribute or make it abstract.

diagnostics.title: "params" should be used instead of "varargs"
diagnostics.description: A method using the VarArgs calling convention is not Common Language Specification (CLS) compliant and might not be accessible across programming languages, while the params keyword works the same way and is CLS compliant.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use the 'params' keyword instead of '__arglist'.

diagnostics.title: Operator overloads should have named alternatives
diagnostics.description: Operator overloading is convenient but unfortunately not portable across languages. To be able to access the same functionality from another language you need to provide an alternate named method following the convention:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Implement alternative method '{0}' for the operator '{1}'.

diagnostics.title: Non-flags enums should not be marked with "FlagsAttribute"
diagnostics.description: This rule raises an issue when an externally visible enumeration is marked with FlagsAttribute and one, or more, of its values is not a power of 2 or a combination of the other defined values.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove the 'FlagsAttribute' from this enum.

diagnostics.title: Method overloads should be grouped together
diagnostics.description: For clarity, all overloads of the same method should be grouped together. That lets both users and maintainers quickly understand all the current available options.
diagnostics.messageFormat: All '{0}' method overloads should be adjacent.

diagnostics.title: Duplicate values should not be passed as arguments
diagnostics.description: There are valid cases for passing a variable multiple times into the same method call, but usually doing so is a mistake, and something else was intended for one of the arguments.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Verify that this is the intended value; it is the same as the {0} argument.

diagnostics.title: Collection elements should not be replaced unconditionally
diagnostics.description: It is highly suspicious when a value is saved for a key or index and then unconditionally overwritten. Such replacements are likely errors.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Verify this is the index/key that was intended; a value has already been set for it.

diagnostics.title: Methods should not have identical implementations
diagnostics.description: When two methods have the same implementation, either it was a mistake - something else was intended - or the duplication was intentional, but may be confusing to maintainers. In the latter case, one implementation should invoke the other.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Update this method so that its implementation is not identical to '{0}'.

diagnostics.title: Empty collections should not be accessed or iterated
diagnostics.description: When a collection is empty it makes no sense to access or iterate it. Doing so anyway is surely an error; either population was accidentally omitted or the developer doesn't understand the situation.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this call, the collection is known to be empty here.

diagnostics.title: Classes should implement their "ExportAttribute" interfaces
diagnostics.description: In the Attributed Programming Model, the ExportAttribute declares that a part "exports", or provides to the composition container, an object that fulfills a particular contract. During composition, parts with imports that have matching contracts will have those dependencies filled by the exported object.
diagnostics.messageFormat: {0} '{1}' on '{2}' or remove this export attribute.

diagnostics.title: Native methods should be wrapped
diagnostics.description: Native methods are functions that reside in libraries outside the virtual machine. Being able to call them is useful for interoperability with applications and libraries written in other programming languages, in particular when performing platform-specific operations. However doing so comes with extra risks since it means stepping out of the security model of the virtual machine. It is therefore highly recommended to take extra steps, like input validation, when invoking native methods. This is best done by making the native method private and by providing a wrapper that performs these extra steps and verifications.

diagnostics.title: Null checks should not be used with "is"
diagnostics.description: There's no need to null test in conjunction with an is test. null is not an instance of anything, so a null check is redundant.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this unnecessary null check; 'is' returns false for nulls.

diagnostics.title: Windows Forms entry points should be marked with STAThread
diagnostics.description: When an assembly uses Windows Forms (classes and interfaces from the System.Windows.Forms namespace) its entry point should be marked with the STAThreadAttribute to indicate that the threading model should be "Single-Threaded Apartment" (STA) which is the only one supported by Windows Forms.

diagnostics.title: Members should not have conflicting transparency annotations
diagnostics.description: Transparency attributes, SecurityCriticalAttribute and SecuritySafeCriticalAttribute are used to identify code that performs security-critical operations. The second one indicates that it is safe to call this code from transparent, while the first one does not. Since the transparency attributes of code elements with larger scope take precedence over transparency attributes of code elements that are contained in the first element a class, for instance, with a SecurityCriticalAttribute can not contain a method with a SecuritySafeCriticalAttribute.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Change or remove this attribute to be consistent with its container.

diagnostics.title: Serialization constructors should be secured
diagnostics.description: Because serialization constructors allocate and initialize objects, security checks that are present on regular constructors must also be present on a serialization constructor. Failure to do so would allow callers that could not otherwise create an instance to use the serialization constructor to do this.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Secure this serialization constructor.

diagnostics.title: "P/Invoke" methods should not be visible
diagnostics.description: Methods marked with the System.Runtime.InteropServices.DllImportAttribute attribute use Platform Invocation Services to access unmanaged code and should not be exposed. Keeping them private or internal makes sure that their access is controlled and properly managed.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make this 'P/Invoke' method private or internal.

diagnostics.title: Events should have proper arguments
diagnostics.description: When raising an event, two arguments are expected by the EventHandler delegate: Sender and event-data. There are three guidelines regarding these parameters:

diagnostics.title: Extension methods should not extend "object"
diagnostics.description: Creating an extension method that extends object is not recommended because it makes the method available on every type. Extensions should be applied at the most specialized level possible, and that is very unlikely to be object.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor this extension to extend a more concrete type.

diagnostics.title: Extensions should be in separate namespaces
diagnostics.description: It makes little sense to create an extension method when it is possible to just add that method to the class itself.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Either move this extension to another namespace or move the method inside the class itself.

diagnostics.title: "ConstructorArgument" parameters should exist in constructors
diagnostics.description: When creating a custom Markup Extension that accepts parameters in WPF, the ConstructorArgument markup must be used to identify the discrete properties that match these parameters. However since this is done via a string, the compiler will not notice if there are typos.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Change this 'ConstructorArgumentAttribute' value to match one of the existing constructors arguments.

diagnostics.title: Methods should be named according to their synchronicities
diagnostics.description: According to the Task-based Asynchronous Pattern (TAP), methods returning either a System.Threading.Tasks.Task or a System.Threading.Tasks.Task<TResult> are considered "asynchronous". Such methods should use the Async suffix. Conversely methods which do not return such Tasks should not have an "Async" suffix in their names.

diagnostics.title: Getters and setters should access the expected fields
diagnostics.description: Properties provide a way to enforce encapsulation by providing public, protected or internal methods that give controlled access to private fields. However in classes with multiple fields it is not unusual that cut and paste is used to quickly create the needed properties, which can result in the wrong field being accessed by a getter or setter.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor this {0} so that it actually refers to the field '{1}'.

diagnostics.title: "Shared" parts should not be created with "new"
diagnostics.description: Marking a class with PartCreationPolicy(CreationPolicy.Shared), which is part of Managed Extensibility Framework (MEF), means that a single, shared instance of the exported object will be created. Therefore it doesn't make sense to create new instances using the constructor and it will most likely result in unexpected behaviours.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Refactor this code so that it doesn't invoke the constructor of this class.

diagnostics.title: Weak SSL/TLS protocols should not be used
diagnostics.description: Older versions of SSL/TLS protocol like "SSLv3" have been proven to be insecure.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Change this code to use a stronger protocol.

diagnostics.title: Cryptographic keys should be robust
diagnostics.description: Most of cryptographic systems require a sufficient key size to be robust against brute-force attacks.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use a key length of at least {0} bits for {1} cipher algorithm.{2}

diagnostics.title: "PartCreationPolicyAttribute" should be used with "ExportAttribute"
diagnostics.description: The PartCreationPolicyAttribute attribute, which is part of the Managed Extensibility Framework (MEF), is used to specify how the exported object will be created. Therefore it doesn't make sense not to export this a class with this attribute using the ExportAttribute attribute.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Add the 'ExportAttribute' or remove 'PartCreationPolicyAttribute' to/from this class definition.

diagnostics.title: AES encryption algorithm should be used with secured mode
diagnostics.description: Encryption algorithms can be used with various modes. Some combinations are not secured:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use a certified third party library implementing Galois/Counter Mode (GCM) instead.

diagnostics.title: LDAP connections should be authenticated
diagnostics.description: An LDAP client authenticates to an LDAP server with a "bind request" which provides, among other, a simple authentication method.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Set the 'AuthenticationType' property of this DirectoryEntry to 'AuthenticationTypes.Secure'.

diagnostics.title: Parameter validation in yielding methods should be wrapped
diagnostics.description: Because of the way yield methods are rewritten by the compiler (they become lazily evaluated state machines) any exceptions thrown during the parameters check will happen only when the collection is iterated over. That could happen far away from the source of the buggy code.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Split this method into two, one handling parameters check and the other handling the iterator.

diagnostics.title: Parameter validation in "async"/"await" methods should be wrapped
diagnostics.description: Because of the way async/await methods are rewritten by the compiler, any exceptions thrown during the parameters check will happen only when the task is observed. That could happen far away from the source of the buggy code or never happen for fire-and-forget tasks.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Split this method into two, one handling parameters check and the other handling the asynchronous code.

diagnostics.title: Calls to "async" methods should not be blocking
diagnostics.description: Making blocking calls to async methods transforms something that was intended to be asynchronous into a synchronous block. Doing so can cause deadlocks and unexpected blocking of context threads.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Replace this use of '{0}' with '{1}'.

diagnostics.title: Unread "private" fields should be removed
diagnostics.description: Private fields only used to store values without reading them later is a case of dead store. So changing the value of such field is useless and most probably indicates a serious error in the code.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this unread {0} field '{1}' or refactor the code to use its value.

diagnostics.title: Delivering code in production with debug features activated is security-sensitive
diagnostics.description: Delivering code in production with debug features activated is security-sensitive. It has led in the past to the following vulnerabilities:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make sure this debug feature is deactivated before delivering the code in production.

diagnostics.title: "default" clauses should be first or last
diagnostics.description: switch can contain a default clause for various reasons: to handle unexpected values, to show that all the cases were properly considered.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Move this 'default:' case to the beginning or end of this 'switch' statement.

diagnostics.title: ASP.NET HTTP request validation feature should not be disabled
diagnostics.description: ASP.Net has a feature to validate HTTP requests to prevent potentially dangerous content to perform a cross-site scripting (XSS) attack. There is no reason to disable this mechanism even if other checks to prevent XXS attacks are in place.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Enable input validation for this HttpPost method.

diagnostics.title: "new Guid()" should not be used
diagnostics.description: When the syntax new Guid() (i.e. parameterless instantiation) is used, it must be that one of three things is wanted:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use 'Guid.NewGuid()' or 'Guid.Empty' or add arguments to this Guid instantiation.

diagnostics.title: Calls to delegate's method "BeginInvoke" should be paired with calls to "EndInvoke"
diagnostics.description: Calling the BeginInvoke method of a delegate will allocate some resources that are only freed-up when EndInvoke is called. This is why you should always pair BeginInvoke with an EndInvoke to complete your asynchronous call.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Pair this "BeginInvoke" with an "EndInvoke".

diagnostics.title: Non-async "Task/Task<T>" methods should not return null
diagnostics.description: Returning null from a non-async Task/Task<T> method will cause a NullReferenceException at runtime. This problem can be avoided by returning Task.FromResult<T>(null) instead.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Do not return null from this method, instead return 'Task.FromResult<T>(null)', 'Task.CompletedTask' or 'Task.Delay(0)'.

diagnostics.title: String offset-based methods should be preferred for finding substrings from offsets
diagnostics.description: Looking for a given substring starting from a specified offset can be achieved by such code: str.Substring(startIndex).IndexOf(char1). This works well, but it creates a new string for each call to the Substring method. When this is done in a loop, a lot of strings are created for nothing, which can lead to performance problems if str is large.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Replace '{0}' with the overload that accepts an offset parameter.

diagnostics.title: Using regular expressions is security-sensitive
diagnostics.description: Using regular expressions is security-sensitive. It has led in the past to the following vulnerabilities:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make sure that using a regular expression is safe here.

diagnostics.title: Encrypting data is security-sensitive
diagnostics.description: Encrypting data is security-sensitive. It has led in the past to the following vulnerabilities:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make sure that encrypting data is safe here.

diagnostics.title: Using weak hashing algorithms is security-sensitive
diagnostics.description: Cryptographic hash algorithms such as MD2, MD4, MD5, MD6, HAVAL-128, HMAC-MD5, DSA (which uses SHA-1), RIPEMD, RIPEMD-128, RIPEMD-160, HMACRIPEMD160 and SHA-1 are no longer considered secure, because it is too easy to create hash collisions with them (little computational effort is enough to find two or more different inputs that produces the same hash).
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make sure that hashing data is safe here.

diagnostics.title: Configuring loggers is security-sensitive
diagnostics.description: Configuring loggers is security-sensitive. It has led in the past to the following vulnerabilities:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make sure that this logger's configuration is safe.

diagnostics.title: Using Sockets is security-sensitive
diagnostics.description: Using sockets is security-sensitive. It has led in the past to the following vulnerabilities:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make sure that sockets are used safely here.

diagnostics.title: Using command line arguments is security-sensitive
diagnostics.description: Using command line arguments is security-sensitive. It has led in the past to the following vulnerabilities:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make sure that command line arguments are used safely here.

diagnostics.title: Reading the Standard Input is security-sensitive
diagnostics.description: Reading Standard Input is security-sensitive. It has led in the past to the following vulnerabilities:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make sure that reading the standard input is safe here.

diagnostics.title: Server certificates should be verified during SSL/TLS connections
diagnostics.description: Validation of X.509 certificates is essential to create secure SSL/TLS sessions not vulnerable to man-in-the-middle attacks.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Enable server certificate validation on this SSL/TLS connection

diagnostics.title: Controlling permissions is security-sensitive
diagnostics.description: The access control of an application must be properly implemented in order to restrict access to resources to authorized entities otherwise this could lead to vulnerabilities:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make sure that permissions are controlled safely here.

diagnostics.title: "ValueTask" should be consumed correctly
diagnostics.description: ValueTask<TResult> was introduced in .NET Core 2.0 to optimize memory allocation when functions return their results synchronously.

diagnostics.title: Expanding archive files without controlling resource consumption is security sensitive
diagnostics.description: Successful Zip Bomb attacks occur when an application expands untrusted archive files without controlling the size of the expanded data, which can lead to denial of service. A Zip bomb is usually a malicious archive file of a few kilobytes of compressed data but turned into gigabytes of uncompressed data. To achieve this extreme compression ratio, attackers will compress irrelevant data (eg: a long string of repeated bytes).
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make sure that decompressing this archive file is safe.

diagnostics.title: Using clear-text protocols is security-sensitive
diagnostics.description: Clear-text protocols as ftp, telnet or non secure http are lacking encryption of transported data. They are also missing the capability to build an authenticated connection. This mean that any attacker who can sniff traffic from the network can read, modify or corrupt the transported content. These protocol are not secure as they expose applications to a large range of risk:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Using {0} protocol is insecure. Use {1} instead.

diagnostics.title: Using clear-text protocols is security-sensitive
diagnostics.description: Clear-text protocols as ftp, telnet or non secure http are lacking encryption of transported data. They are also missing the capability to build an authenticated connection. This mean that any attacker who can sniff traffic from the network can read, modify or corrupt the transported content. These protocol are not secure as they expose applications to a large range of risk:
diagnostics.messageFormat: EnableSsl should be set to true.

diagnostics.title: Encryption algorithms should be used with secure mode and padding scheme
diagnostics.description: To perform secure cryptography, operation modes and padding scheme are essentials and should be used correctly according to the encryption algorithm:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use secure mode and padding scheme.

diagnostics.title: Cipher algorithms should be robust
diagnostics.description: Strong cipher algorithms are cryptographic systems resistant to cryptanalysis, they are not vulnerable to well-known attacks like brute force attacks for example.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use a strong cipher algorithm.

diagnostics.title: JWT should be signed and verified with strong cipher algorithms
diagnostics.description: If a JSON Web Token (JWT) is not signed with a strong cipher algorithm (or not signed at all) an attacker can forge it and impersonate user identities.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Use only strong cipher algorithms when verifying the signature of this JWT.

diagnostics.title: Deserializing objects without performing data validation is security-sensitive
diagnostics.description: Deserialization process extracts data from the serialized representation of an object and reconstruct it directly, without calling constructors. Thus, data validation implemented in constructors can be bypassed if serialized objects are controlled by an attacker.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Make sure not performing data validation after deserialization is safe here.

diagnostics.title: Types allowed to be deserialized should be restricted
diagnostics.description: Failure to control types during deserialization can lead to runtime errors and vulnerabilities. There are many types, called "gadgets" (see ysoserial.net) which are known to be not secure when deserializing.

diagnostics.title: Literal suffixes should be upper case
diagnostics.description: Using upper case literal suffixes removes the potential ambiguity between "1" (digit 1) and "l" (letter el) for declaring literals.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Upper case this literal suffix.

diagnostics.title: Increment (++) and decrement (--) operators should not be used in a method call or mixed with other operators in an expression
diagnostics.description: The use of increment and decrement operators in method calls or in combination with other arithmetic operators is not recommended, because:
diagnostics.messageFormat: Extract this {0} operation into a dedicated statement.

diagnostics.title: "goto" statement should not be used
diagnostics.description: goto is an unstructured control flow statement. It makes code less readable and maintainable. Structured control flow statements such as if, for, while, continue or break should be used instead.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Remove this use of 'goto'.

diagnostics.title: Parameter names should match base declaration and other partial definitions
diagnostics.description: The name of a parameter in an externally visible method override does not match the name of the parameter in the base declaration of the method, or the name of the parameter in the interface declaration of the method or the name of any other partial definition.
diagnostics.messageFormat: Rename parameter '{0}' to '{1}' to match the {2} declaration.
